"Hymn to Freedom" {{center|[[File:Greece national anthem.ogg]]}} | image_flag = State Flag of Greece (1863-1924 and 1935-1970).svg | image_coat = Royal Coat of Arms of Greece.svg | image_map = Hellenic Republic (1935).svg | image_map_caption = | capital = [[Athens]] | common_languages = [[Greek language]] | religion = [[Greek Orthodox]] | government_type =[[Unitary state|Unitary]] [[Metaxism|Metaxist]] [[constitutional monarchy]] under a [[totalitarianism|totalitarian]] [[dictatorship]] | title_representative = [[Monarchy of Greece|King]] | representative1 = [[George II of Greece|George II]] | year_representative1 = 1936–1941 | title_leader = [[List of Prime Ministers of Greece|Prime Minister]] | leader1 = [[Ioannis Metaxas]] | leader2 = [[Alexandros Koryzis]] | leader3 = [[Emmanouil Tsouderos]] | year_leader1 = 1936–1941 | year_leader2 = 1941 | year_leader3 = 1941 | currency = [[Greek drachma]] | year_start = 1936 | date_start = 4 August | event_end = End | date_end = May | year_end = 1941 }} {{History of Greece}} The '''4th of August Regime''' ({{lang-el|Καθεστώς της 4ης Αυγούστου}}, ''Kathestós tis tetártis Avgoústou''), commonly also known as the '''Metaxas Regime''' ({{lang-el|Καθεστώς Μεταξά}}, ''Kathestós Metaxá''), was a [[Totalitarianism|totalitarian]] regime under the leadership of [[General]] [[Ioannis Metaxas]] that ruled the [[Kingdom of Greece]] from 1936 to 1941. On 4 August 1936, Metaxas, with the support of [[George II of Greece|King George II]], suspended the [[Hellenic Parliament|Greek parliament]] and went on to preside over a [[Conservatism#Greece|conservative]], staunchly [[anti-communist]] government. The regime took inspiration in its symbolism and rhetoric from [[Kingdom of Italy#Fascist regime (1922–1943)|Fascist Italy]], but never developed into a fully-fledged fascist dictatorship, and retained close links to Britain and the [[French Third Republic]], rather than the [[Axis powers]]. Lacking a popular base, after Metaxas' death in January 1941 the regime hinged entirely on the King. Although Greece was occupied following the [[German invasion of Greece]] in April 1941 and the Greek government was [[Greek government in exile|forced into exile]] in the [[Middle East]], several prominent figures and features of the regime, notably the notorious security chief [[Konstantinos Maniadakis]], survived for several months in cabinet until the King was forced to dismiss them in a compromise with the representatives of the old democratic political establishment. == Origins of the regime == {{also|Metaxism}} Metaxas imposed his regime primarily to fight the turbulent social situation prevalent in Greece in the 1930s, in which political factionalization had disrupted Greek [[parliamentary democracy]]. The sinking credibility of the Parliament was accompanied by several [[coup d'etat|coup]] attempts; in March 1935, a [[Venizelism|Venizelist]] [[putsch]] failed, and in the following October, elections reinforced the [[monarchist|Royalist]] majority, which allowed the exiled [[George II of Greece|King George II]] to return to Greece. The king re-established the [[Kings of Greece|monarchy]] in the country, but the parliament, split into incompatible factions, was unable to shape a clear political majority so that the government could govern. Meanwhile, the increasing activity of the [[Communist Party of Greece|Communists]], whose 15 deputies from the 1936 elections held the balance between 143 Monarchists and 142 Liberals, Agrarians, and Republicans, created a deadlock. In May 1935 widespread agrarian unrest (tobacco farmers) and industrial unrest in the north of the country erupted, which eventually brought General Metaxas to suspend the parliament on the eve of a major strike, on 4 August 1936. Endorsed by the King, Metaxas declared a [[state of emergency]], decreed [[martial law]], annulled various articles of the constitution and established a crisis cabinet to put to an end the growing riots and to restore social order. In one of his first speeches, Metaxas announced: "I have decided to hold all the power I need for saving Greece from the catastrophes which threaten her." Thus the Metaxas dictatorship was born, and the period of time which would follow was named after the day Metaxas rose to absolute power: the 4th of August. The new regime was backed by small extreme political parties, and by conservatives expecting a crackdown on the communists. === Classical influences === [[File:Metaxas-regime-greek-fascism.png|thumb|250px|Young members of the Greek [[National Organisation of Youth]] (EON) hail in presence of Ioannis Metaxas.Metaxas Jugend - A picture album of the Greek Fascist Youth EON (2009), p.11]] The roots of Metaxas' "New State" were sought in Greece's classical history. Metaxas thought Hellenic nationalism would galvanize "the heathen values of [[ancient Greece]], specifically those of [[Sparta]], along with the Christian values of the Medieval empire of [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantium]]".Clogg (1992) [[Ancient Macedonia]] was also glorified as the first political unifier of the Hellenes.Hamilakis, Y. (2007) ''The nation and its ruins: antiquity, archaeology, and national imagination in Greece'', Oxford University Press, {{ISBN|0-19-923038-2}}, p. 177 As its main symbol, the youth organization of the regime chose the [[labrys]]/[[pelekys]], the symbol of ancient Minoan Crete. The traditional Greek values of "Country, Loyalty, Family and Religion", which Metaxas praised repeatedly, were also close to those of the ancient Spartans. The regime promoted the perceived Spartan ideals of [[self-discipline]], [[militarism]] and collective sacrifice, while Byzantium provided an emphasis on a centralized state and devotion to the [[Greek monarchy|monarchy]] and [[Greek Orthodox Church]].Hamilakis (2007), pp. 177-178 === External influences === Metaxas considered [[António de Oliveira Salazar|António Salazar]]'s [[Estado Novo Portugal|Estado Novo]] of [[Portugal]] his main inspiration{{Citation needed|date=December 2012}} and surrounded himself with elements from this and other dictatorial regimes of the time. Thus his main ideological slogan was also "New State" (''Neon Kratos'') and the 4th of August regime used its own military-like uniforms, greetings, songs and rituals, including the [[Roman salute]] (which Metaxas considered Greek in origin as a salutation to the sun god Apollo, and he referred to it as the "Hellenikos Hairetismos" ("Hellenic Hailing")).{{Citation needed|date=August 2018}} In Metaxas' case we can speak as well of some characteristics typical of authoritarian states such as 1930s Italy and Germany: the regime's propaganda presented Metaxas as "the First Peasant", "the First Worker" and as "the National Father" of the Greeks. Like his contemporaries Hitler with Führer and Mussolini with Duce, Metaxas adopted the title of ''Arhigos'', Greek for "leader" or "chieftain", and claimed that his regime had to lay the foundations for the appearance of a glorious "Third Hellenic Civilization" combining the best of ancient Greece and the Greek [[Byzantine Empire]] of the [[Middle Ages]]. == Greek totalitarianism == {{details|Metaxism}} The Metaxas regime sought to comprehensively change Greece, and therefore instituted controls on Greek society, politics, language, and the economy. In each of these, the Metaxas government resembled more closely the policies that Spain would adopt later on than those of their contemporaries Nazi Germany or Fascist Italy. {{quote|''Greece since the 4th of August became an anticommunist State, an antiparliamentary State, a totalitarian State. A State based on its farmers and workers, and so antiplutocratic. There is not, of course, a particular party to govern. This party is all the People, except of the incorrigible communists and the reactionary old parties politicians.''|Ioannis Metaxas|Metaxas' diary p.553}} === Attempts at social control === Having come to power with the stated intent of restoring public order, Metaxas' state largely achieved this goal, under the supervision of what can be described as its most fascist member, minister of public order [[Konstantinos Maniadakis]]. Maniadakis created a second fake "communist party", published a fake "[[Rizospastis]]" and achieved the dissolution of all the communist organizations. Metaxas' policies such as the [[censorship]] of the media, the banning of political parties and prohibition of [[Strike action|strikes]] copied contemporary European authoritarian regimes. As its far-right contemporaries Italy and Germany, the Greek State also had its political police force, the ''Asfaleia'', based upon the [[Gestapo]] (its chief Maniadakis maintained a close relationship with Himmler on methods and techniques). The objective of Asfaleia was to secure public order. The regime also repressed the [[rebetiko]] music due to the uncompromising lyrics and favoured the traditional [[Greek folk music]]. Hashish dens, [[baglamas]] and [[bouzouki]] were banned, or at least playing in the [[Arabian maqam|eastern-style manner]] and scales. Probably inspired by the ''[[Völkisch movement]]'', a massive promotion of the [[Greek folk music]] took place, though the radio and public festivals, mainly because of the animosity of the state towards the bouzoukis and the rebetiko music. On this point the Greek communist left agreed, considering the rebetiko as "reactionary". Soon after its inception the regime severely repressed the communists and leftists. About 15,000 people were arrested and jailed, or exiled for political reasons; some were subjected to torture. Metaxas' regime forced the Communist party underground, and also attempted to dismantle the old system of loyalties of the Royalist and Venizelist parties. Those major forces however remained, as they had for the preceding decades, and re-emerged immediately after the four-year Metaxas regime. While Metaxas' regime did play up a supposed communist threat in order to justify its repression, the regime is not known to have committed political murders and did not instate the death penalty. Dissidents were, rather, usually banished to tiny islands in the [[Aegean sea]]. For example, the liberal leader [[George Papandreou, senior|George Papandreou]] was exiled to [[Andros]]. The [[Greek Communist Party]] (KKE), meanwhile, which had already been outlawed, remained intact. Legal restrictions against it finally were ended in 1974 during [[metapolitefsi]]. ===Arts and Culture=== Metaxas, educated in the [[German Empire]] and admirer of the German culture, gave emphasis to the Art production (theatrical, literary, musical, visual arts etc.). He collaborated with significant intellectual figures of the era, like [[Stratis Myrivilis]], [[Nikos Kazantzakis]], [[Angelos Sikelianos]], [[Manolis Kalomoiris]], [[Angelos Terzakis]], [[Nelly's]] and others, to promote the ideas of the regime, especially to the youth. Another notable policy was the use and promotion of the [[Demotic Greek]] (''Demotiki'') in the educational system -but in a conservative form-, instead of the ''[[Katharevousa]]''. [[Manolis Triantafyllidis]] was appointed for the creation of the grammar. === The role of youth === {{main|National Youth Organisation (Greece)}} [[File:EON on parade.jpg|thumb|250px|[[National Organisation of Youth|EON]] on parade (from its official magazine ''I Neolaia''). The [[Labrys|double axe]], emblem of the organisation, is visible on the standard.]] [[File:Ethniki Organosis Neoleas emblem.svg|thumb|140px|The emblem of EON.]] [[File:Flag of EON.svg|thumb|The flag which was used by EON during the Fourth of August regime.]] In order to keep and maintain the values of the regime in future years, Metaxas gave birth to the ''Ethniki Organosi Neolaias'' (Εθνική Οργάνωση Νεολαίας, [[National Organisation of Youth]], EON). The EON brought together youths of all economic and social strata into one single body. Boys’ education emphasized discipline and physical training, while girls were taught to become supportive wives and caring mothers to breed a stronger, healthier new generation. The EON published a fortnightly magazine called ''Neolaia'' (Νεολαία, Greek for "Youth"), which had much influence both in schools and in higher education. Metaxas' vision was to create, through the youth, the "Third Hellenic Civilization", a continuity of the ancient Greek and Byzantine civilization. The EON was disbanded by the German-Italian occupying authority in Greece following its vigorous resistance of the invasion. === Nationalism === As in most other totalitarian regimes, the 4th of August regime adopted a strong nationalistic program: although Metaxas was opposed to the invasion of Asia Minor as part of the [[Megali Idea]], he used strong nationalist language concerning Greek minorities in neighbouring countries {{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} and in answering threats from Greece's neighbours in the still volatile southeast Europe. As with many nation states at the time, he used language exalting his people's "race". Ethnic (mainly Slavic speakers) and religious minorities were persecuted under Metaxas' rule.Kallis The regime, however, was relatively tolerant to the [[History of the Jews in Greece|Greek Jews]], repealing the anti-Semitic laws of previous regimes. A large community of Sephardic Jews was present in the region of Thessaloniki which was annexed by Greece in 1913, and Jews were largely in opposition to [[Venizelism]]. Metaxas was firmly opposed to the irredentist factions of the Slavophones of northern Greece (consisting of Macedonians and Bulgarians mainly in Aegean Macedonia and Thrace), some of whom underwent political persecution due to advocacy of irredentism with regard to neighbouring countries. Metaxas' regime continued repression of the use of Slavic languages both in public and in private and of expressions of Slavic cultural distinctiveness. Despite their supposed disloyalty, however, Slavophone Greeks identified with the Greek state and fought ferociously for Greece on the Italo-Albanian front. Again in contrast to some totalitarian regimes, no mass killings were ever instituted and there is no evidence that any were planned. === Economic policy === One of the 4th of August government's main objectives was the repudiation of the old capitalist system and its replacement with a [[corporatism|corporatist economic system]] in order to promote national and social solidarity. This idea "harmonized perfectly with Metaxas' convictions on social and national solidarity as well as his rejection of individualism and class struggle". The plan for the creation of a corporatist state was manifest in the early days of the regime by public declarations by Metaxas and by government ministers.Constantine Sarandis, "The Ideology and Character of the Metaxas Regime", ''The Metaxas Dictatorship: Aspects of Greece, 1936-1940'', pages 156-157. To this end, Deputy Premier and Finance Minister [[Konstantinos Zavitsianos]] "published details about a horizontal (according to branches of production), not vertical (according to social class), syndicalist organization" of the state. However, due to the external crisis with Italy, the plan had to be temporarily postponed with the result that it never fully materialized. Metaxas' government, initially unpopular, also gained popularity through an elaborate program to socialize the Greek economy, including: * [[unemployment insurance]] * [[maternity leave]]. * a five-day, 40-hour workweek. * guaranteed two-week vacations with pay (or two weeks' double pay in place of the vacation). * stricter work safety standards. Many elements of this program persist in Greek economic policy. Metaxas' regime founded the Workers' Center (Εργατικό Κέντρο), which was established to look after workers' housing and recreation, among other things. The 4th of August regime initially stabilized the [[drachma]], which had been suffering from high inflation. Exploiting the newfound solidity of the currency, Metaxas' government embarked on large [[public works]] programs (such as the [[Ellinikon International Airport]]), including [[drainage system (agriculture)|land drainage]], construction of railways, road improvements, and modernization of the telecommunications infrastructure. Metaxas' economic program met with initial success, with a marked rise in [[per capita income]] and temporary decline in unemployment in Greece between 1936 and 1938 (unemployment skyrocketed after 1938). Capitalizing on this success, the government instituted [[debt relief]] for farmers and instituted [[price floor]]s on some agricultural goods to redistribute wealth to the countryside. Also, on the legislation sector the Greek civil code, was finally completed by a jurist commission; a plan pending since the years of [[Otto of Greece]]. ==Other== Another organization established by the regime was for the first time a state radio station; the YRE, suitable also for the propaganda of the regime. == Differences from other totalitarian regimes == There is some debate over how the regime relates to other totalitarian regimes of the 1930s, especially [[Italian Fascism]] and German [[Nazism]]. [[Richard Clogg]] argues that while the regime had "superficial trappings of Fascism" and Metaxas "did not disguise his admiration for Nazism and Fascism", it is "more correctly categorised as paternalist-authoritarian rather than fascist".Clogg (1987), p. 182 Some of the main and important differences of Metaxas' regime as compared to fascism proper include: *The anti-imperialist speech of the regime. *The pro-Jewish stance of Metaxas and tolerance to religious minorities. *The emphasis on the progress of the Greek Arts and Culture (as a plan for the ''[[Third Hellenic Civilization]]''). *Absence of a mass political base for the regime, in the form of a political party or movement. *No representative architecture or monuments. == The end of the 4th of August regime == [[File:GambierParryMetaxasJorgeIIDalbiacYPapagosEnero1941--128421.jpeg|thumb|250px|[[Ioannis Metaxas]] with [[George II of Greece|King George II]] and [[Alexandros Papagos]] during a meeting of the Anglo-Greek War Council.]] Foreign policy was one of the main concerns of the 4th of August regime. Metaxas, who had studied in Germany as a youth, was pro-German, while the King was pro-British. This caused heated discussions between the two, but the reality of 1930s Europe was that Greece's security depended less on Germany than on her traditional protector, the [[United Kingdom]], which was the [[Great Power]] dominating the Eastern [[Mediterranean Sea]] with her fleet. In addition, Italian leader Benito Mussolini's grandiose schemes to build a [[new Roman Empire]] in the Mediterranean directly clashed with Greek pretensions to control the Aegean Sea and the [[Dodecanese islands]] (by then under Italian control) and to exert stronger influence in Albania. As tensions and threat of war increased in Europe just before World War II, the situation was almost exactly the same as the position before World War I, when Greece had strong pro-German affinities in government, but it depended on Britain for its security. Most observers were anticipating Greece would attempt to remain neutral. Metaxas indeed attempted to maintain strict neutrality, but Italian expansionism eventually led to an Italian ultimatum and to the [[Greco-Italian War]]. However, Greek forces repelled the Italian invasion completely and brought the Italian soldiers back into Albania, where the invasion had been launched. In fact, some territories in Albania [[Greek minority in Albania|where a Greek minority lives]] were claimed to be 'alliberated' and Metaxas' plans were to unite them with the rest of Greece. Metaxas died suddenly in January 1941 among dark circumstances. His death raised hopes of a liberalization of his regime and the restoration of parliamentary rule, but King George quashed these hopes when he retained the regime's machinery in place. In the meantime, [[Adolf Hitler]] was reluctantly{{says who?|date=June 2017}} forced to divert German troops to rescue Mussolini from defeat, and began [[Battle of Greece]] through [[Kingdom of Yugoslavia|Yugoslavia]] and Bulgaria on 6 April 1941. Despite British assistance, by the end of May, the Germans had overrun most of the country. The King and the government escaped to Crete, where they stayed until the end of the [[Battle of Crete]]. They then transferred to [[Kingdom of Egypt|Egypt]], where a [[Greek government in exile]] was established. Meanwhile, in Greece a fascist puppet government was placed into power by the Axis. == Legacy == As the Axis occupation ended, Greece descended into [[Greek Civil War|civil war]] between the communist-dominated forces of the left, operating in Greece and from bases in the south of Yugoslavia, and the U.S.- and UK-aligned forces of the political right. This was the first major protracted combat of the [[Cold War]], one of the first exercises in U.S. policy of [[Containment]], and a subject of the [[Truman Doctrine]] of U.S. President [[Harry Truman]]. The alignments were quite different from the Venizelist-Monarchist National Schism, as most Venizelists supported the right-wing alliance during the civil war. == See also == * [[4th of August Party]] * [[1938 Greek coup d'état attempt]] * [[Golden Dawn (political party)|Golden Dawn]] * [[Regime of the Colonels]] == Footnotes == {{Reflist}} == References == * Clogg, Richard. The '''Aga Khan Foundation''' ('''AKF''') is a private, [[Nonprofit organization|not-for-profit]] [[International development|international development agency]],<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.pk/books?id=gTuMg-WbLvcC&pg=PP13&dq=akf+development+agency&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwia0KeN98bQAhVEWhoKHcM0CgsQ6AEIGDAA#v=onepage&q=akf%20development%20agency&f=false|title=Improving Schools Through Teacher Development: Case Studies of the Aga Khan Foundation Projects in East Africa|last=Anderson|first=S. E.|date=2002-01-01|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=9789026519369|language=en}}</ref> which was founded in 1967 <ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.pk/books?id=oBxyaj3b50EC&pg=PA18&dq=akf+1967&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjGw6-v98bQAhVRahoKHYTDAQ8Q6AEIHDAB#v=onepage&q=akf%201967&f=false|title=International Encyclopedia of Civil Society|last=Anheier|first=Helmut K.|last2=Toepler|first2=Stefan|date=2009-11-24|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=9780387939964|language=en}}</ref> by [[Aga Khan IV|Prince Shah Al Hussaini, Aga Khan IV]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.pk/books?id=Oe0GDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA153&dq=akf+by+aga+khan&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjA7sfR98bQAhVL7hoKHReuDwMQ6AEIRzAH#v=onepage&q=akf%20by%20aga%20khan&f=false|title=Global Religious Movements Across Borders: Sacred Service|last=Cherry|first=Stephen M.|last2=Ebaugh|first2=Helen Rose|date=2016-04-22|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317127338|language=en}}</ref> AKF seeks to provide long-term solutions to problems of [[poverty]], [[hunger]], [[Literacy|illiteracy]] and [[Health|ill health]] in the poorest parts of [[South Asia|South]] and [[Central Asia]], Eastern and Western [[Africa]], and the [[Middle East]]. In these regions, the needs of rural communities in mountainous, coastal and other resource-poor areas are given particular attention. The Foundation's activities often reinforce the work of other sister agencies within the [[Aga Khan Development Network]] (AKDN). While these agencies are guided by different mandates pertaining to their respective fields of expertise (the environment, culture, microfinance, health, education, architecture, rural development), their activities are often coordinated with one another in order to "multiply" the overall effect that the Network has in any given place or community. AKF also collaborates with local, national and international partners in order to bring about sustainable improvements of life in the 19 countries in which it works. The Foundation's head office is located in [[Geneva]], [[Switzerland]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.pk/books?id=g6uztzPOqtUC&pg=PA147&dq=akf+headquarters+geneva&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwinibbz98bQAhUF1RoKHeVfAAUQ6AEIKTAD#v=onepage&q=akf%20headquarters%20geneva&f=false|title=NGOs and Organizational Change: Discourse, Reporting, and Learning|last=Ebrahim|first=Alnoor|date=2005-05-12|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=|isbn=9780521671576|location=|pages=147|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref>
==Areas of focus== The Foundation concentrates its resources on selected issues in [[health]], [[education]], [[rural development]], [[Natural environment|environment]] and the strengthening of [[civil society]]. Seeking innovative approaches to generic problems, it tries to identify solutions that can be adapted to conditions in many different regions and replicated.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.pk/books?id=amPc4uJALpIC&pg=PA172&dq=akf+focus&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjW0uO1-MbQAhUFWxoKHa3GDcg4ChDoAQgXMAA#v=onepage&q=akf%20focus&f=false|title=Teaching Korea: Modernization, Model Minorities, and American Internationalism in the Cold War Era|last=|first=|date=2008-01-01|publisher=ProQuest|year=|isbn=9781109098709|location=|pages=172|language=en|quote=|via=}}</ref>
Cross-cutting issues that are also addressed by the Foundation include [[Training and development|human resource development]], [[Community-driven development|community participation]], and [[gender and development]].
==Funding and grant making== The Aga Khan Foundation is the principal [[Grant-in-aid|grant-making]] agency for social development within the [[Aga Khan Development Network]]. Grants are normally given to local organizations interested in testing new solutions, in learning from experience and in being agents of lasting change. These organizations must share the Foundation's and [[Aga Khan Development Network|Aga Khan Development Network's]] goals in their specific areas of focus. If no established group exists, the Foundation occasionally creates new organizations to tackle particularly important problems.
The Aga Khan provides the Foundation with regular funding for administration as well as making contributions to its endowment. The [[Isma'ilism|Ismaili]] community contributes volunteers, time, professional services and substantial financial resources. Other funding sources include income from investments and grants from government, institutional and private sector partners, as well as donations from individuals around the world.
One programme series funded by the Foundation was the [[BBC World News]] television series ''Architects on the Frontline'', which was about entries to the [[Aga Khan Award for Architecture]] competition, and was criticized by the media watchdog [[Ofcom]] for breaking United Kingdom broadcasting rules; viewers were not informed that the series, which praised the competition, was sponsored content.<ref>{{cite news|website=BBC News|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-33971919|title=News channels breached sponsorship rules, Ofcom says|date=18 August 2015|access-date=18 August 2015}}</ref>
==Awards and recognition== Among other recognition for its work, the Foundation received the 2005 Award for Most Innovative Development Project from the Global Development Network for the [[Aga Khan Rural Support Programme]] (AKRSP). The AKRSP has successfully been replicated to form the [[Rural Support Programmes Network]] in [[Pakistan]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20060815165947/http://www.gdnet.org/middle.php?primary_link_id=3&secondary_link_id=9 Global Development Network: Global Development Awards<!-- bot-generated title -->] at www.gdnet.org</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.pk/books?id=IV9m8gF6XDcC&pg=PA162&dq=AKRSP+replication&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjMxtTT9sbQAhXCXhoKHVPjBrIQ6AEIOjAH#v=onepage&q=AKRSP%20replication&f=false|title=Ending Poverty in South Asia: Ideas that Work|last=Narayan-Parker|first=Deepa|last2=Glinskaya|first2=Elena E.|date=2007-01-01|publisher=World Bank Publications|isbn=9780821368770|language=en}}</ref>
==Geographic focus== The Foundation normally intervenes where it has a strong volunteer base. It is currently active in the following countries: [[Afghanistan]], [[Bangladesh]], [[Canada]], [[Egypt]], [[India]], [[Kenya]], [[Kyrgyzstan]], [[Madagascar]], [[Mozambique]], [[Pakistan]], [[Portugal]], [[Switzerland]], [[Syria]], [[Tajikistan]], [[Tanzania]], [[Uganda]], [[United Kingdom]], and [[United States]].
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Sources== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20120124003155/http://www.akdn.org/publications/2011_akf_continuum.pdf AKF and AKDN: A Continuum of Development]
==External links== *{{Official website|www.akdn.org/akf}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2014}} {{Infobox person | name = Amal Clooney | image = Amal Clooney 02.jpg | caption = Clooney in 2018 | birth_name = Amal Alamuddin | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1978|2|3|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Beirut]], Lebanon | nationality = {{hlist|[[British nationality law|British]]|[[Lebanese nationality law|Lebanese]]}} | alma_mater = {{plainlist| * [[St Hugh's College, Oxford]] * [[New York University School of Law]]}} | occupation = [[Barrister|Barrister-at-law]] | years_active = 2000–present | spouse = {{marriage|[[George Clooney]]|2014}} | children = 2 }} '''Amal Clooney''' (''[[Given name#Name at birth|née]]'' '''Alamuddin'''; {{lang-ar| أمل علم الدين}}; born 3 February 1978)<ref name="People-40thBday-2018">{{cite news|last1=Russian|first1=Ale|title=Amal's Big 40! George Clooney Celebrates Wife's Birthday on 24-Hour Getaway|url=http://people.com/movies/amals-big-40-george-clooney-celebrates-wifes-birthday-on-24-hour-getaway/|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=5 February 2018|language=en}}</ref> is a Lebanese-British [[barrister]] at [[Doughty Street Chambers]], specialising in international law and human rights.<ref name="NYDailyNews-Engagement-2014">{{cite news|last1=Nicole Lyn|first1=Pesce|last2=Dillon|first2=Nancy|last3=Rivera|first3=Zayda|title=George Clooney Finally Meets His Match With Human Rights Lawyer Amal Alamuddin|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/george-clooney-hitched-lawyer-amal-alamuddin-article-1.1772111|work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|date=29 April 2014}}</ref> Her clients include the likes of [[Julian Assange]], the founder of [[WikiLeaks]], in his fight against extradition,<ref name="ABCNews-5Things-2014">{{cite news|work=[[ABC News]]|url=http://www.abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/things-george-clooneys-lady-friend-amal-alamuddin/story?id=22960268|last=Rothman|first=Michael|title=5 Things About Amal Alamuddin|date=19 March 2014}}</ref> the former prime minister of Ukraine, [[Yulia Tymoshenko]],<ref name="Independent-Engagement-2014">{{cite news|first1=Ian|last1=Johnston|title=George Clooney Engaged To Amal Alamuddin: Actor To Marry British Human Rights Lawyer Who Has Represented Julian Assange|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/news/george-clooney-to-marry-his-british-lawyer-girlfriend-amal-alamuddin-9294602.html|work=[[The Independent]]|date=27 April 2014}}</ref> and Egyptian-Canadian journalist [[Mohamed Fahmy]]. She is married to the American actor [[George Clooney]].<ref name="People-40thBday-2018" />
== Early life and family == Amal Alamuddin was born in [[Beirut]], [[Lebanon]]. Her first name is derived from [[Arabic language|Arabic]] [[wikt:أمل|أمل]] ''{{transl|ar|ALA-LC|ʾamal}}'', meaning "hope".<ref name=ManVs.Society-Amal-Meaning-2014>{{cite book|last1=Rosenthal|first1=Franz|editor1-last=Gutas|editor1-first=Dimitri|title=Man Versus Society in Medieval Islam|date=2014|publisher=Brill|location=Leiden; Boston|ISBN=978-9-004-27089-3|page=613|url=https://www.worldcat.org/title/man-versus-society-in-medieval-islam/oclc/892338528/viewport|OCLC=892338528}}</ref>
During the 1980s [[Lebanese Civil War]], Alamuddin's family left [[Lebanon]] and settled in [[Gerrards Cross]], [[Buckinghamshire]].<ref name=Telegraph-Engagement-2014>{{cite news|last1=Flanagan|first1=Padraic|title=George Clooney Engaged to High-Flying British Lawyer|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/10793797/George-Clooney-engaged-to-high-flying-British-lawyer.html|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=28 April 2014}}</ref> She learned English watching her favourite show “The Facts of Life," and was two years old at the time.<ref name=AlArabiya-WhoIs-2014>{{cite news|last1=Karam|first1=Joyce|title=Who is Clooney's fiancée Amal Alamuddin?|url= http://english.alarabiya.net/en/life-style/entertainment/2014/04/28/Who-is-Clooney-s-fianc-e-Amal-Alamuddin-.html|accessdate=28 September 2014|work=[[Al Arabiya]]|date=28 April 2014}}</ref> Her father, Ramzi Alam Uddin, from a [[Druze in Lebanon|Lebanese Druze]] family from [[Baakline]] (a village in the Chouf district),<ref name="AlArabiya-WhoIs-2014" /><ref name=GlobeDailyMail>{{cite news|author1=Globe Staff|title=George Clooney rejects Daily Mail's apology for 'fabricated' story |accessdate=21 August 2014|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/celebrity-news/george-clooney-rejects-daily-mails-apology-for-fabricated-story/article19565361/|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|publisher=Phillip Crawley |date=11 July 2014|quote=whose father, Ramzi, belongs to a prominent Druze family. }}</ref><ref name="DailyStar-DruzeCommunity-2014">{{cite news|title=Talk of the village: What does Amal Alamuddin's Druze community think of Clooney engagement? |url=http://www.albawaba.com/limelight/george-clooney-amal-alamuddin-578965|accessdate=21 August 2014|work=[[The Daily Star (Lebanon)|The Daily Star]]|publisher=[[Al Bawaba]]|date=26 May 2014}}</ref><ref name="DailyStar-Baaqlin-2014">{{cite news|title=Clooney, Alamuddin set Sept. 20 marriage date|url=http://www.dailystar.com.lb/Life/Lubnan/2014/Aug-08/266415-clooney-alamuddin-set-sept-20-marriage-date.ashx|accessdate=28 September 2014|work=[[The Daily Star (Lebanon)|Daily Star]]|date=8 August 2014}}</ref><ref name="ArabDailyNews-Druze-2014">{{cite news |last1=Younes|first1=Ali|title=Who is Amal Alamuddin, reported George Clooney's new fiancee|url=http://thearabdailynews.com/2014/04/30/amal-alamuddin-reported-george-clooneys-new-fiancee/|accessdate=28 September 2014|work=The Arab Daily News|date=30 April 2014}}</ref><ref name="WeeklyStandard-Druze-2014">{{cite news |last1=Smith|first1=Lee|title=But Is It Good for the Druze?George Clooney and his future in-laws|url=http://www.weeklystandard.com/articles/it-good-druze_791179.html|accessdate=28 September 2014|work=[[The Weekly Standard]]|date=19 May 2014|volume=19|issue=34}}</ref> received his [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]] degree at the [[American University of Beirut]] and was the owner of COMET travel agency. He returned to Lebanon in 1991.<ref name="StraitsTimes-Engagement-2014">{{cite news|work=[[The Straits Times]]|date=27 April 2014|accessdate=6 May 2014|url=http://www.straitstimes.com/lifestyle/movies/story/george-clooneys-fiancee-not-only-has-beauty-and-brains-also-great-style-20140|title=George Clooney's Fiancée Amal Alamuddin Has Beauty, Brains And Style}}</ref><ref name="Amal Family Background Info">{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/middle-east/lebanon/140504/youd-think-george-clooney-amal-alamuddin-marriage|title=You'd think George Clooney asked all of Lebanon to marry him|newspaper=[[Global Post]]}}</ref> Her mother, Bariaa Miknass, from a family of [[Sunni Islam in Lebanon|Sunni Muslims]]<ref name="NOW-Druze-2014"/><ref name="NBCNews-DruzeSunni-2014"/> from [[Tripoli, Lebanon|Tripoli]] in Northern Lebanon,<ref name="NOW-Druze-2014">{{cite news|last1=Gebeily|first1=Maya|title=Amal Alamuddin from 'Druze family of sheikhs'|url=https://now.mmedia.me/lb/en/reportsfeatures/545333-amal-alamuddin-from-druze-family-of-sheikhs|accessdate=28 September 2014|website=[[NOW News]]|date=30 April 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006172909/https://now.mmedia.me/lb/en/reportsfeatures/545333-amal-alamuddin-from-druze-family-of-sheikhs|archive-date=6 October 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="NBCNews-DruzeSunni-2014">{{cite news|last1=Gatten|first1=Emma|title=Amal Alamuddin: George Clooney's Betrothed a Star Among Druze Community|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/amal-alamuddin-george-clooneys-betrothed-star-among-druze-community-n201351|accessdate=28 September 2014|work=[[NBC News]]|date=13 September 2014}}</ref> is a foreign editor of the [[Pan-Arab]] newspaper ''[[al-Hayat]]'' and a founder of the public relations company International Communication Experts, which is part of a larger company that specialises in celebrity guest bookings, publicity photography, and event promotion.<ref name="AlArabiya-WhoIs-2014" /><ref name="GlobellComm-2010">{{cite web|url=http://www.globellcommunications.com/ice/ice.html|title=International Communication Experts (I.C.E.)|website=Globell Communications|date=2010}}</ref>
Alamuddin's mother, Baria Alamuddin,is a well-known political journalist.<ref>[https://www.tatler.com/article/amal-clooney-the-most-wanted-woman-in-britain Amal Clooney - the most wanted woman in Britain], Matthew Bell tries to hang out with Mrs Clooney, [[Tatler]], Tuesday, 19 January 2016: '"I remember her as humane and brainy," adds [[Ghil'ad Zuckermann]], now a professor of linguistics at the University of Adelaide, Australia, who was also at St Hugh's with Amal. "Students were talking about Amal even then, especially those from Middle Eastern backgrounds. I remember being told around 1997 about her '''famous journalist mother'''."'</ref> She states, “My pregnancy with Amal was a rather difficult one,” as she had [[placenta praevia]] and spent two months in the hospital. “At some point, I was told that I should lose the baby. I said no. I kept on having these dreams in which I would see her face and how she was going to look. In the end, [she] was born exactly as I saw her.” The birth came during a lull in Lebanon's civil war, so her father named her Amal{{snd}} Arabic for “hope.”
Amal Clooney has three siblings—one sister, Tala, and two half-brothers, Samer and Ziad,<ref name="AlArabiya-WhoIs-2014" /> from her father's first marriage.<ref name="NOW-LebanonPride-2014">{{cite news|agency=AFP|title=Lebanon in frenzy over Clooney-Alamuddin engagement|url=https://now.mmedia.me/lb/en/lebanonnews/545482-lebanon-in-frenzy-over-clooney-alamuddin-engagement|accessdate=28 September 2014|website=[[NOW News]]|date=1 May 2014}}{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
== Education == Clooney attended [[Dr Challoner's High School]], a girls' [[grammar school]] located in [[Little Chalfont]], [[Buckinghamshire]]. She then studied at [[St Hugh's College, Oxford]], where she received an [[Exhibition (scholarship)|Exhibition]]<ref name=OxfordGazette>{{cite news|newspaper=[[Oxford University Gazette]]|date=23 October 1997|title=Colleges, Halls, and Societies: Notices – St Hugh's College|url=http://www.ox.ac.uk/gazette/1997-8/weekly/231097/coll.htm|access-date=6 May 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100718195832/http://www.ox.ac.uk/gazette/1997-8/weekly/231097/coll.htm|archive-date=18 July 2010|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and the Shrigley Award.<ref name="Forbes-Engaged-2014">{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/gregorymcneal/2014/04/27/international-lawyer-and-scholar-amal-alamuddin-engaged-to-george-clooney/|title=International Lawyer And Scholar Amal Alamuddin Engaged To George Clooney|work=[[Forbes (magazine)|Forbes]]|date=27 April 2014|first=Gregory S.|last=McNeal|accessdate=15 September 2014}}</ref> In 2000, Clooney graduated with a [[Bachelor of Arts|BA]] degree in [[Jurisprudence]] (Oxford's equivalent to the [[Bachelor of Laws|LLB]])<ref name="Oxford-2013">{{cite web|title=Law (Jurisprudence)|accessdate=8 April 2014|work=[[University of Oxford]]|url=http://www.ox.ac.uk/admissions/undergraduate_courses/courses/law_jurisprudence/law.html}}</ref> from St Hugh's College, Oxford.
The following year, in 2001, she entered [[New York University School of Law]] to study for the [[Master of Laws|LLM]] degree. She received the Jack J. Katz Memorial Award for excellence in entertainment law.<ref name="DoughtyStreet-BioPDF-2014">{{cite web|title=Amal Alamuddin|work=[[Doughty Street Chambers]]|format=[[PDF]]|url=http://www.doughtystreet.co.uk/barristers/profile-pdf/amal-clooney/185|access-date=14 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150731002805/http://www.doughtystreet.co.uk/barristers/profile-pdf/amal-clooney/185#|archive-date=31 July 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="IBT-6FastFacts-2014">{{cite web|last=Schumann|first=Rebecka|title=George Clooney Girlfriend Revealed: Who Is Amal Alamuddin? 6 Fast Facts About The Actor's New Love|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/george-clooney-girlfriend-revealed-who-amal-alamuddin-6-fast-facts-about-actors-new-love-photos |newspaper=[[International Business Times]]|date=29 October 2013|accessdate=6 May 2014}}</ref> For one semester while at NYU, she worked in the office of [[Sonia Sotomayor]], then a judge for the [[United States Court of Appeals]] for the [[Second Circuit]].<ref name="Slate-Engaged-2014">{{cite news|last1=Mathis-Lilley|first1=Ben|title=London Human Rights Lawyer Amal Alamuddin Is Engaged|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/the_slatest/2014/04/28/amal_alamuddin_london_lawyer_to_wed_actor.html|accessdate=28 September 2014|work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]|date=28 April 2014}}</ref>
== Career == Clooney is qualified to practice as a lawyer in the United States and the United Kingdom. She was admitted to the bar in New York in 2002 and in England and Wales in 2010. She has also practiced at international courts in The Hague including the International Court of Justice and the International Criminal Court.<ref name="DoughtyStreet-BioPDF-2014"/>
=== New York === Amal worked at [[Sullivan & Cromwell]] in New York City for three years as part of the Criminal Defense and Investigations Group, where her clients included [[Enron]] and [[Arthur Andersen]].<ref name="Forbes-Engaged-2014"/><ref name="DoughtyStreet-BioPDF-2014"/>
=== The Hague === In 2004, she completed a judicial clerkship at the [[International Court of Justice]]. She clerked under Judge Vladlen S. Vereshchetin from Russia, Judge [[Nabil Elaraby]] from Egypt,<ref name="IILJ-Clerkship-2004-2005">{{cite web|title=Clerkships – Prior and Present Clerks|url=http://www.iilj.org/oldbak/experience/Clerkships2.htm|website=Institute for International Law and Justice|publisher=[[New York University School of Law]]|accessdate=28 September 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140904095632/http://www.iilj.org/oldbak/experience/Clerkships2.htm|archive-date=4 September 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="People-5FastFacts-2014">{{cite web|last=Chi|first=Paul|title=George Clooney Engaged to Amal Alamuddin: 5 Fast Facts About Her |accessdate=6 May 2014|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20791492,00.html|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=27 February 2014}}</ref> and ad hoc [[Franklin Berman|Judge Sir Franklin Berman]] from the United Kingdom.
She was subsequently based in The Hague working in the Office of the Prosecutor at the UN [[Special Tribunal for Lebanon]] and at the [[International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia]].<ref name="ExpandingJurisdiction-2010">{{cite journal|volume=8|issue=5|page=1219|url=http://jicj.oxfordjournals.org/content/8/5/1219.full|journal=Journal of International Criminal Justice|title=Expanding Jurisdiction over War Crimes under Article 8 of the ICC Statute|doi=10.1093/jicj/mqq066|last1=Alamuddin |first1=A.|last2=Webb|first2=P.|year=2010}}</ref>
=== London === Clooney returned to Britain in 2010,<ref name="Standard-Caseload-2014">{{cite news|last1=Butter|first1=Susannah|title=Amal Alamuddin's caseload: why the future Mrs George Clooney isn't about to give up her day job as a human rights lawyer|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/london-life/amal-alamuddins-caseload-why-the-future-mrs-george-clooney-isnt-about-to-give-up-her-day-job-as-a-human-rights-lawyer-9680615.html|accessdate=28 September 2014|work=[[London Evening Standard]]|date=20 August 2014}}</ref> where she became a barrister in London (Bar of England & Wales, [[Inner Temple]]) at [[Doughty Street Chambers]].<ref name="Forbes-Engaged-2014" /> In 2013 Clooney was appointed to a number of United Nations commissions, including as adviser to Special Envoy [[Kofi Annan]] on Syria and as Counsel to the 2013 Drone Inquiry by UN human rights rapporteur Ben Emmerson QC into the use of drones in counter-terrorism operations.<ref name="IBT-6FastFacts-2014" /><ref name="UNSRCTDroneInquiry-2013">{{cite web|title=UN SRCT Drone Inquiry – Credits: UNSRCT Team |url=http://unsrct-drones.com/report/176|accessdate=28 April 2014|work=[[United Nations]]}}</ref>
Clooney has been involved in high-profile cases representing the state of Cambodia, the former Libyan intelligence chief [[Abdullah Senussi|Abdallah Al Senussi]], [[Yulia Tymoshenko]]<ref name="BBCNews-TymoshenkoInterview-2014">{{cite news|title=BBC News Amal Alamuddin on Yulia Tymoshenko and Ukraine|url=https://vimeo.com/90740322|accessdate=30 August 2015|work=[[BBC News]]|date=2 April 2014}}</ref> and [[Julian Assange]], and was an adviser to the King of Bahrain in connection with the Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry headed by Professor [[M. Cherif Bassiouni]].<ref name="DoughtyStreet-BioPDF-2014" />
== Teaching == For the Spring 2015 and 2016 academic semesters, Clooney was a visiting faculty member and a senior fellow with [[Columbia Law School]]'s [[Human Rights Institute]].<ref name=VFair-Columbia-teaching-2015>{{cite web|last1=Duboff|first1=Josh|title=Amal Clooney Will Be Teaching at Columbia Law School This Spring|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/2015/03/amal-clooney-columbia-law-school|work=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|date=6 March 2015|accessdate=7 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=ColumbiaLawSchool-Maldives-2016>{{cite news|last1=Frankel|first1=Mark|title=From Morningside Heights to the Maldives|url=http://www.law.columbia.edu/media_inquiries/news_events/2016/may2016/amal-clooney-columbia|work=[[Columbia Law School]]|date=12 May 2016|language=en|format=Press release}}</ref> She was a co-professor with [[Sarah Cleveland|Sarah H. Cleveland]] in Cleveland's course on human rights and taught a class on human rights litigation to students in the school's Human Rights Clinic.<ref name=People-ColumbiaTeaching-2015>{{cite news|last1=Andriakos|first1=Jacqueline|title=Amal Clooney to Teach at Columbia Law School in N.Y.C.|url=http://www.people.com/article/amal-clooney-teach-columbia-law-school-joins-faculty|accessdate=7 March 2015|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=7 March 2015}}</ref><ref name=ColumbiaLaw-VisitingProf-2015>{{cite web|title=Amal Clooney: Visiting Professor and Senior Fellow, Human Rights Institute (Spring 2015)|url=https://www.law.columbia.edu/fac/Amal_Clooney|website=[[Columbia Law School]]|accessdate=14 May 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150518092112/https://www.law.columbia.edu/fac/Amal_Clooney|archive-date=18 May 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
For the Spring 2018 semester, Clooney taught at [[Columbia Law School]], again as a co-professor with [[Sarah Cleveland|Sarah H. Cleveland]] on a core class on human rights.<ref name=ColumbiaLawSchool-HumanRightsCourse-2018>{{cite news|title=Amal Clooney Returns to Columbia Law to Teach International Human Rights Law|url=http://www.law.columbia.edu/news/2018/03/amal-clooney-returns-international-human-rights|work=[[Columbia Law School]]|date=23 March 2018|language=en}}</ref>
Clooney has also lectured students on international criminal law at the [[SOAS School of Law|Law School of the School of Oriental and African Studies, University of London]], [[The New School]] in New York City, [[The Hague Academy of International Law]], and the [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]].<ref name="DoughtyStreet-BioPDF-2014" />
== Notable cases == [[File:UNICEF UK (14281378624) (cropped).jpg|thumb|Amal in May 2014]] As of 2011, Clooney was assisting the [[Permanent Court of Arbitration]] in the arbitration between [[Merck Sharp and Dohme]] and the [[Republic of Ecuador]].<ref name="PCA-Merck-Ecuador-2011">{{cite web|title=Merck Sharpe & Dohme (I.A.) LLC v. The Republic of Ecuador|url=http://www.pca-cpa.org/showpagea11a.html?pag_id=1486|website=[[Permanent Court of Arbitration]]|accessdate=30 August 2015|date=2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150910013754/http://www.pca-cpa.org/showpagea11a.html?pag_id=1486|archive-date=10 September 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Starting in 2014, Clooney represented [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[Al Jazeera English]] journalist [[Mohamed Fahmy]] who, along with other journalists, was being held in Egypt.<ref name="Guardian-Fahmy-2014">{{cite news|last1=Kingsley|first1=Patrick|title=Amal Clooney calls on Egypt to release journalist Mohamed Fahmy|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/nov/06/amal-clooney-egypt-journalist-mohamed-fahmy|accessdate=16 July 2015|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=6 November 2014}}</ref><ref name="CBCNews-Fahmy-2015">{{cite news|last1=Paris|first1=Max|title=Amal Clooney wants Stephen Harper to 'pick up phone' to free Mohamed Fahmy|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/amal-clooney-wants-stephen-harper-to-pick-up-phone-to-free-mohamed-fahmy-1.2974284|accessdate=16 July 2015|work=[[CBC News]]|date=26 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="GlobeMail-Fahmy-2015">{{cite news|last1=Galloway|first1=Gloria|title=Amal Clooney to travel to Egypt to lobby for Fahmy’s freedom|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/amal-clooney-to-travel-to-egypt-to-lobby-for-fahmys-freedom/article23217265/|accessdate=16 July 2015|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=26 February 2015}}</ref><ref name="GlobalNews-Fahmy-2015">{{cite news|last1=Logan|first1=Nick|title=Mohamed Fahmy’s lawyer Amal Clooney pens deportation request ahead of verdict|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/2113410/mohamed-fahmys-lawyer-amal-clooney-pens-deportation-request-ahead-of-retrial-verdict/|accessdate=16 July 2015|work=[[Global News]]|date=15 July 2015}}</ref> He was eventually sentenced to three years in prison and lost a retrial in August 2015 before finally being pardoned by Egyptian president Abdel Fattah al-Sisi.<ref name="Guardian-AlJazeera-Sentence-2015">{{cite news|last1=Malsin|first1=Jared|title=Al-Jazeera journalists sentenced to three years in prison by Egyptian court|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/aug/29/egyptian-court-sentences-3-al-jazeera-english-journalists-to-3-years-in-prison|accessdate=30 August 2015|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=29 August 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Mohamed Fahmy, Canadian journalist, pardoned by Egyptian president, released from prison|url = http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/mohamed-fahmy-pardoned-egypt-1.3239822|accessdate = 2015-10-06}}</ref>
In August 2014, Clooney declined a UN commission to look into possible violations of the rules of war in Gaza during the Gaza war of 2014.<ref name="YahooCelebrity-Horrified-2014">{{cite web |last=Ryder|first=Taryn|title=Amal Alamuddin 'Horrified,' but Unable to Serve on Gaza Rights U.N. Probe|work=[[Yahoo! In January 2015, Clooney began work on the recognition of the [[Armenian Genocide]].<ref name="Telegraph-ArmGeno-2015">{{cite news|last1=Waterfield|first1=Bruno|title=Amal Clooney accuses Turkey of hypocrisy on freedom of speech in Armenian genocide trial|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/turkey/11373991/Amal-Clooney-accuses-Turkey-of-hypocrisy-on-freedom-of-speech-in-Armenian-genocide-trial.html|accessdate=28 January 2015|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=28 January 2015}}</ref> She is representing Armenia on behalf of Doughty Street Chambers along with Geoffrey Robertson QC.<ref name="Telegraph-TurkeyArmenia-2015">{{cite news|last1=Akkoc|first1=Raziye|title=Amal Clooney's latest case: Why Turkey won't talk about the Armenian genocide|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/europe/turkey/11373115/Amal-Clooneys-latest-case-Why-Turkey-wont-talk-about-the-Armenian-genocide.html|accessdate=28 January 2015|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=28 January 2015}}</ref> She said Turkey's stance was hypocritical "because of its disgraceful record on freedom of expression", including prosecutions of Turkish-Armenians who campaign for the 1915 massacres to be called a genocide.<ref name="Telegraph-ArmGeno-2015" /> She is representing Armenia in the case against [[Doğu Perinçek]],<ref name="News.am-ECHR-2015">{{cite web|title=Amal Clooney’s speech in ECHR hearing of Perinçek v. == Philanthropy == Clooney is the president of the Clooney Foundation for Justice, which she co-founded with her husband George Clooney in late 2016 to advance justice in courtrooms, communities, and classrooms around the world.
Clooney partnered with the Aurora Humanitarian Initiative in beginning the Amal Clooney Scholarship, which was created to send one female student from Lebanon to the [[United World College Dilijan]] each year, to enroll in a two-year International Baccalaureate (IB) programme.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/gossip/la-et-mg-amal-clooney-scholarship-100-lives-20151217-story.html|title=Amal Clooney launches scholarship for Lebanese girls|author=Los Angeles Times|date=17 December 2015|work=latimes.com}}</ref>
Clooney and her husband sponsor a Yazidi student, Hazim Avdal, who Clooney met via her work with [[Nadia Murad]] as Avdal worked at [[Yazda]]. He is attending the [[University of Chicago]].<ref name=ChicagoTrib-HazimAvdal-2018>{{cite news|last1=Swartz|first1=Tracy|title=George and Amal Clooney sponsor an Iraqi refugee attending U. of C.|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/chicagoinc/ct-ent-george-clooney-iraqi-refugee-hazim-avdal-20180212-story.html|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=12 February 2018}}</ref>
In 2018, following the [[Stoneman Douglas High School shooting]], the Clooneys pledged $500,000 to the [[March for Our Lives]] and said they would be in attendance.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/the-wrap/article/George-and-Amal-Clooney-Donate-500-000-for-12626898.php|title=Oprah Follows George and Amal Clooney’s Lead, to Donate $500,000 for Parkland Students’ March|date=20 February 2018|publisher=}}</ref>

page.title: Amendments to the Citizenship Law (popular initiative, Latvia)

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
'''Amendments to the Citizenship Law''' of Latvia, suggested by a popular initiative in 2012, sought to grant citizenship of Latvia, starting in 2014, to those [[non-citizens (Latvia)|non-citizens]] who would not refuse it. The proposed amendments were rejected by the Central Election Commission. The CEC decision was contested by the proponents of the amendments, who applied to court. The court proceedings were suspended in 2013, with the Supreme Court requesting the [[Constitutional Court of Latvia|Constitutional Court]] to decide on the compliance of some applicable provisions with the Constitution.
==The draft law and gathering signatures==
In 2011, the party [[ForHRUL]] initiated gathering signatures (certified by notaries) for amendments to the [[Latvian nationality law|Citizenship law]].<ref>[http://rus.delfi.lv/news/daily/politics/zapchel-nachinaet-sbor-podpisej-za-referendum-po-nulevomu-variantu.d?id=40370427 ЗаПЧЕЛ начинает сбор подписей за референдум по "нулевому варианту"] [[Delfi (web portal)|DELFI]] 2011{{ru icon}}</ref> The amendments provide to add to the Section 2 of the law (establishing which groups form the circle of citizens of Latvia) the following Clause 6: “Since 1 January 2014 – non-citizens, who have not submitted an application on keeping the status of a non-citizen until 30 November 2013, in a manner to be determined by the Cabinet of Ministers” and to add some transitional provisions.
In May, 2012, the Minister of Justice [[Gaidis Bērziņš]] has commented on the collection of signatures through his spokesperson, stating that the public officials should "exclude the opportunity to be involved in a situation which could be understood as subversive and compromising"<ref>[http://www.tm.gov.lv/lv/jaunumi/tm_info.html?news_id=4163 Tieslietu ministrs aicina ikvienu amatpersonu apzināties savu atbildību pret valsti] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120513005546/http://www.tm.gov.lv/lv/jaunumi/tm_info.html?news_id=4163 |date=2012-05-13 }}{{lv icon}}</ref> The parliamentary group of the [[Harmony Centre]] has filed a question to the minister, considering him to exert pressure upon notaries.<ref>[http://titania.saeima.lv/LIVS11/saeimalivs_lmp.nsf/0/CA3A916CECCA6E17C22579FA00240426?OpenDocument Nr. 7/P11]{{lv icon}}</ref>
In August, 2012, it was announced, that the 10,000 signatures, necessary at the first stage, are collected. Prime Minister [[Valdis Dombrovskis]] has expressed hope that there will be no second stage of gathering signatures and called the Central Election Commission to consider, whether the second stage should be conducted.<ref>[http://rus.delfi.lv/news/daily/politics/premer-nado-podumat-sobirat-li-voobsche-podpisi-za-referendum-o-negrazhdanah.d?id=42629076 Премьер: надо подумать, собирать ли вообще подписи за референдум о негражданах] [[Delfi (web portal)|DELFI]] 2012{{ru icon}}</ref> The President's chancery invited the CEC to consider not only the legal drafting, but also the content of the draft law.<ref>[http://rus.delfi.lv/news/daily/politics/proekt-o-negrazhdanah-berzinsh-somnevaetsya-v-kachestve.d?id=42636522 Проект о негражданах: Берзиньш сомневается в качестве] [[Delfi (web portal)|DELFI]] 2012{{ru icon}}</ref>
==Consideration by the Central Election Commission==
On 4 September 2012, the signatures were submitted to the Central Election Commission. On 27 September, the CEC postponed deciding on the destiny of the draft law.<ref>[http://rus.delfi.lv/news/daily/politics/referendum-po-negrazhdanam-cik-otlozhil-reshenie.d?id=42703446 Референдум по негражданам: ЦИК отложил решение] [[Delfi (web portal)|DELFI]] 2012 {{ru icon}}</ref>
The CEC' verification confirmed that the draft law was signed by the necessary number of voters (12,686 valid signatures of citizens, while 10,000 were needed at the organisers' paid stage). On 1 November 2012, the CEC decided by 6 votes to 2 with 1 abstaining, that the draft law is not consistent with the [[Constitution of Latvia|Constitution]], namely the state continuity doctrine, and consequently cannot be considered fully elaborated; therefore it should not be referred to the state-paid stage of collection of signatures.<ref>[http://web.cvk.lv/pub/public/30441.html Lēmums Nr. 6]{{lv icon}}</ref>
==Trials==
The CEC decision was appealed against in two lawsuits, by those who submitted the draft law to CEC and by one of those who signed the draft law, both cases being launched in November, according to the general order of appeals against CEC decisions (before the administrative district court).<ref>[http://rus.delfi.lv/news/daily/politics/referendum-po-negrazhdanam-sudebnaya-tyazhba-nachalas.d?id=42856792 Референдум по негражданам: судебная тяжба началась] [[Delfi (web portal)|DELFI]] 26.11.2012 {{ru icon}}; [http://www.baltic-course.com/eng/legislation/?doc=65494 Kuzins contests decision to halt signature drive for "non-citizen referendum" in Latvia] The Baltic Course</ref>
On December 11, 2012, a set of amendments to the law on legislative initiatives, adopted on November, 8, came into force.<ref>[http://likumi.lv/doc.php?id=252963 Grozījumi likumā "Par tautas nobalsošanu, likumu ierosināšanu un Eiropas pilsoņu iniciatīvu"]{{lv icon}}</ref> It provides the CEC with the competence to refuse gathering signatures on the grounds of draft law not conforming with the Constitution and provides for a special way of judicial review - such CEC refusals are appealed against before the Department of Administrative Cases of the Supreme Court and must be adjudicated during one month. The administrative district court transferred both cases to the Department of Administrative Cases of the Supreme Court.<ref>[http://rus.delfi.lv/news/daily/politics/referendum-o-negrazhdanah-delo-rassmotryat-v-kratchajshie-sroki.d?id=42913052 Референдум о негражданах: дело рассмотрят в кратчайшие сроки] [[Delfi (web portal)|DELFI]] 18.12.2012{{ru icon}}</ref>
On 11 February 2013, the Department of Administrative Cases of the Supreme Court has adopted a decision<ref>[http://at.gov.lv/files/uploads/files/archive/department3/2013/1-sa-2013.doc Lēmums]{{lv icon}}</ref> to adjourn the proceedings in the case and to request the Constitutional Court to evaluate whether the draft law conforms with the Constitution and [[On the Restoration of Independence of the Republic of Latvia|Declaration of Independence]]. The decision was described as unexpected in the legal journal "Jurista vārds": the opinions of the experts invited by the journal have ranged from "The Senate's actions are well-grounded" to "haven't they mentioned that the Constitutional Court does not evaluate draft laws?".<ref>''Gailīte D.'' [http://www.juristavards.lv/index.php?menu=default&laidiens_id=11645&red_s=1 Bumbas spēle] Jurista vārds Nr. 7 (758) 19.02.2013{{lv icon}}</ref><!-- <ref>[http://www.juridicainternational.eu/index.php?id=15331 Jarinovska, Kristine. "Popular Initiatives as Means of Altering the Core of the Republic of Latvia", ''Juridica International''. Vol. 20, 2013. p. 152 ISSN1406-5509]</ref> -->
On 20 February, the Department of Administrative Cases of the Supreme Court reconsidered its own decision and asked the Constitutional Court another question instead<ref>[http://www.imhoclub.lv/material/referendum_po_grazhdanstvu_budet/page/2 Lēmums]{{lv icon}}</ref> - whether the provisions of the amended law on legislative initiative, which give the competence to review the constitutionality of the draft laws to the CEC and the Supreme Court, conform with the Article 1 of the Constitution (the principle of separation of powers).
On 12 March, the Constitutional Court has launched proceedings on the application by the Department of Administrative Cases of the Supreme Court.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.satv.tiesa.gov.lv/upload/2013-06-01_PR_par_ierosinasanu_ENG.pdf |title=Press Release Case No. 2013-06-01 12.03.2013 |access-date=2013-09-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219234140/http://www.satv.tiesa.gov.lv/upload/2013-06-01_PR_par_ierosinasanu_ENG.pdf |archive-date=2013-12-19 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> On 18 December, the Constitutional Court decided that CEC's and the Supreme Court's competence is constitutional, provided that they only stop initiatives obviously contradicting the Constitution.<ref>[http://www.satv.tiesa.gov.lv/wp-content/uploads/2013/03/2013-06-01_Spriedums_ENG.pdf Judgment in case No. 2013-06-01]</ref>
On 12 February 2014, the Supreme Court has delivered the judgment considering the CEC decision to be lawful.<ref>[http://at.gov.lv/lv/pazinojumi-presei/par-tiesas-sedem/2014/kasacijas-instance/6286-noraida-pieteikumu-par-centralas-velesanu-komisijas-lemuma-atcelsanu/ Noraida pieteikumu par Centrālās vēlēšanu komisijas lēmuma atcelšanu]{{lv icon}}</ref>
