{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox political party | name = Australian Motoring Enthusiast Party |logo = |colorcode = Blue |president = |foundation = 11 May 2013 |dissolved = 8 February 2017 |headquarters = Level 5, Toowong Tower, 9 Sherwood Road, [[Toowong]], [[Queensland]] |country = Australia |founder = |colours = {{Colour box|Blue}} [[Blue]] }} The '''Australian Motoring Enthusiast Party''' was an Australian political party from 2013 to 2017. [[Ricky Muir]] held a seat for the party in the [[Australian Senate]] from 2013 to 2016.
==History== The Australian Motoring Enthusiast Party (AMEP) was formed on 11 May 2013 in Queensland at a public meeting of motoring enthusiasts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.australianmotoringenthusiastparty.org.au/about |title=AMEP - About |accessdate=4 February 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140822051526/http://www.australianmotoringenthusiastparty.org.au/about |archivedate=22 August 2014 }}</ref> The formation of the party followed moves by state governments, particularly in Queensland, to toughen anti-[[hooning]] and vehicle impoundment legislation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.australianmotoringenthusiastparty.org.au/australian_motoring_enthusiast_party_forms |accessdate=4 February 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140226222150/http://www.australianmotoringenthusiastparty.org.au/australian_motoring_enthusiast_party_forms |title=Australian Motoring Enthusiast Party Forms |archivedate=26 February 2014 }}</ref>
The Australian Electoral Commission completed the registration of the AMEP on 9 July 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aec.gov.au/Parties_and_Representatives/Party_Registration/Registered_parties/files/aust-motoring.pdf|format=PDF|title=Register Of Political Parties : The Australian Motoring Enthusiast Party|publisher=Aec.gov.au|accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref>
==Formation and structure== The AMEP's structure includes State Councils and a Central Executive.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.australianmotoringenthusiastparty.org.au/constitution |accessdate=4 February 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140213205834/http://www.australianmotoringenthusiastparty.org.au/constitution |title= The Australian Motoring Enthusiast Party Constitution - April 2013 |archivedate=13 February 2014 }}</ref> The Queensland State Council and the Central Executive were formed when the party was established on 11 May 2013. At that point the Central Executive was made up of the Queensland State Council's office bearers.
The first Annual General Meeting of the AMEP was held on 11 July 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.australianmotoringenthusiastparty.org.au/agm_2013 |accessdate=4 February 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131014175138/http://www.australianmotoringenthusiastparty.org.au/agm_2013 |title=AMEP Annual General Meeting 2013 |archivedate=14 October 2013 }}</ref> The Queensland State Council office bearers were returned as the Central Executive's office bearers.
The Victorian State Council was formed on 17 July 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.australianmotoringenthusiastparty.org.au/victorian_state_council_of_amep_established |accessdate=4 February 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140228072034/http://www.australianmotoringenthusiastparty.org.au/victorian_state_council_of_amep_established |title=Victorian State Council of AMEP Established |author=Scott McDonald |archivedate=28 February 2014 }}</ref> The Western Australian State Council was formed on 23 July 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.australianmotoringenthusiastparty.org.au/western_australian_state_council_established |accessdate=4 February 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140726223934/http://www.australianmotoringenthusiastparty.org.au/western_australian_state_council_established |title=Western Australian State Council Established |date=25 July 2013 |archivedate=26 July 2014 }}</ref> The New South Wales State Council was formed on 7 August 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.australianmotoringenthusiastparty.org.au/new_south_wales_state_council_established |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130818125457/http://www.australianmotoringenthusiastparty.org.au/new_south_wales_state_council_established |title=New South Wales State Council Established |author=Matthew Midson |date=8 August 2013 |archivedate=18 August 2013}}</ref>
The Victorian State Council was suspended by the party's executive in October 2013 over claims that it had set up a [[Facebook]] page without permission and had engaged in what ABC News reported as being labelled "illegal and unauthorised use of AMEP identification, confidential information, incorrect policy announcements, and the misuse of the party brand". The former chairman of the Victorian State Council, Scott McDonald, told the ABC that it was unclear why the action had been taken.<ref>{{cite news |last=Caldwell |first=Alison |title=Australian Motoring Enthusiast Party closes Victorian branch over 'blatant disregard' for national executive |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-10-07/amep-shuts-victorian-branch-ricky-muir/5003480 |accessdate=9 October 2013 |newspaper=ABC News |date=8 October 2013}}</ref>
==2013 Federal election== The party [[Political endorsement| endorsed]] [[Australian Senate|Senate]] candidates in the [[Australian federal election, 2013|2013 Federal Election]] in New South Wales, South Australia, Queensland, Victoria and Western Australia. The party has been involved in [[Glenn Druery]]'s [[Minor Party Alliance]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-09-05/bitter-dispute-erupts-over-senate-preferences-in-queensland/4939300 |title=Bitter dispute erupts over Senate preferences in Queensland |first=Trevor |last=Bormann |publisher=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]] |date=5 September 2013 |access-date=7 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/news/special-features/alliance-of-micro-parties-boosts-odds-for-likes-of-one-nation-or-shooters-and-fishers-gaining-senate-spot-through-preferences/story-fnho52jp-1226713114765 |title=Alliance of micro parties boosts odds for likes of One Nation or Shooters and Fishers gaining Senate spot through preferences |newspaper=Daily Telegraph |date=5 September 2013 |access-date=7 June 2016 |first=Alicia |last=Wood}}</ref>
[[Ricky Muir]] represented AMEP in Victoria and won a seat in the senate after preference distribution from a record-low primary vote of 0.51 percent or 17,122 first preferences<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/federal-election-2013/results/senate/vic/ |title=Senate Results: Victoria |work=ABC News |accessdate=7 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-10-01/motoring-enthusiast-ricky-muir-wins-a-seat-in-australian-senate/4991882|title=Motoring Enthusiasts Party member Ricky Muir wins Senate seat |work=ABC News |accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://blogs.abc.net.au/antonygreen/2013/09/the-preference-deals-behind-the-strange-election-of-ricky-muir-and-wayne-dropulich-.html |title=Antony Green's Election Blog |publisher=Blogs.abc.net.au |accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref> he assumed his seat on 1 July 2014. Larger parties including the incoming government are looking at changes to the [[group voting ticket]] system.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessspectator.com.au/news/2013/9/8/election/election-coalition-shy-senate-majority|title=ELECTION: Coalition shy of Senate majority |publisher=Businessspectator.com.au |accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.watoday.com.au/federal-politics/federal-election-2013/tony-abbott-fires-a-warning-shot-at-micro-parties-in-the-senate-20130909-2tf5b.html |accessdate=7 June 2016 |deadurl=no |title= Tony Abbott fires a warning shot at micro parties in the Senate |first=Dan |last=Harrison |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160131091322/http://www.watoday.com.au/federal-politics/federal-election-2013/tony-abbott-fires-a-warning-shot-at-micro-parties-in-the-senate-20130909-2tf5b.html |archivedate=31 January 2016 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.ninemsn.com.au/national/2013/09/09/08/50/xenophon-wants-voting-reform |title=Xenophon wants voting reform |work=News.ninesn.com.au |accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref>
On 10 October 2013 Muir announced he would enter into an alliance with the [[Palmer United Party]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2013-10-10/clive-palmer-joins-forces-with-motoring-enthusiast-ricky-muir-i/5013556 |title=Clive Palmer issues warning to Government as Motoring Enthusiast Ricky Muir joins Senate voting bloc |publisher=Abc.net.au |date= |accessdate=13 October 2013}}</ref>
Muir's senior adviser was electoral consultant [[Glenn Druery]], but he was sacked by Muir less than a month later and was escorted out of Parliament. Muir stated that Druery did not "get along with the staff".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.theage.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/senator-ricky-muir-sacks-chief-of-staff-glenn-druery-20140801-3cyf5.html |title=Senator Ricky Muir sacks chief of staff Glenn Druery |newspaper=The Age |date=1 August 2014 |first=Heath |last=Aston |accessdate=7 June 2016}}</ref> Muir also hired former [[New South Wales]] state politician [[Peter Breen (Australian politician)|Peter Breen]] to advise him on legislation.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-opinion/novice-politician-ricky-muir-undone-by-a-veteran-in-the-business-or-questionable-tactics-20140609-39se4.html |title=Novice politician Ricky Muir undone by a veteran in the business or questionable tactics? |newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=9 June 2014 |first=Matthew |last=Knott |access-date=7 June 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.smh.com.au/federal-politics/political-news/muir-hires-expollie-to-help-with-legislation-20140701-3b6lg.html | title=Muir hires ex-pollie to help with legislation | work=Sydney Morning Herald | date=2 July 2014 | accessdate=10 July 2014 | author=Aston, Heath}}</ref>
Muir lost his seat at the [[Australian federal election, 2016|federal election]] held on 2 July 2016,<ref name="APH bio Muir">{{cite web|title=Senator Ricky Muir|url=http://www.aph.gov.au/Senators_and_Members/Parliamentarian?MPID=250024|publisher=Parliament of Australia|accessdate=4 August 2016}}</ref> leaving the AMEP without any representation in the federal parliament.
On 8 February 2017, the party voluntarily de-registered with the Australian Electoral Commission.<ref name="dereg">{{cite web|title=Australian Motoring Enthusiast Party|url=http://www.aec.gov.au/Parties_and_Representatives/Party_Registration/Deregistered_parties/amep.htm|website=Australian Electoral Commission|accessdate=9 February 2017}}</ref>

'''Aversive agents''' are unpleasantly flavored substances added to poisonous [[household goods]] in order to discourage [[children]] and animals from consuming the poisonous household products. Aversive agents are not intended to be harmful, only unpleasant. For example, to prevent children from consuming poisonous [[anti-freeze]], which has a [[sweet]] flavor due to the [[ethylene glycol]], an aversive agent is added, which gives the anti-freeze an unpleasant taste. There are two primary classes of aversive agents: [[bitterant]]s, chemicals producing a bitter flavor, and [[pungent agents]], chemicals producing an unpleasantly [[pungent]] flavor.<ref>{{Cite conference|first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Final Report Study of Aversive Agents |booktitle= |pages= |publisher=Consumer Product Safety Commission United States of America |date=18 November 1992 |location= |url=http://www.cpsc.gov/LIBRARY/FOIA/foia99/os/aversive.pdf |doi= |id= |accessdate=15 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110616104140/http://www.cpsc.gov/LIBRARY/FOIA/foia99/os/aversive.pdf |archivedate=16 June 2011 }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Denaturation (food)]], the deliberate addition of an unpleasantly flavored or poisonous substances to food in order to prevent the consumption of the food for various reasons. *[[Adulterant]], a substance added to food for deceptive or malicious reasons, for example to cheaply replace legitimate ingredients. *[[Denatonium]], also known as [[Bitrex]], an aversive agent often added to household products.

The Bloc was formed by [[Members of Parliament]] who defected from the federal [[Progressive Conservative Party of Canada|Progressive Conservative Party]] and [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal Party]] during the collapse of the [[Meech Lake Accord]]. Founder [[Lucien Bouchard]] was a cabinet minister in the federal Progressive Conservative government of [[Brian Mulroney]]. The party seeks to create the conditions necessary for the political secession of [[Quebec]] from Canada and campaigns actively only within the province during federal elections. The [[Canadian federal election, 2011|2011 election]] saw the party win just four seats and lose [[official party status]] after a wave of support for the [[New Democratic Party]]. By 2014 the party had been reduced to two seats because of resignations and expulsions. In the [[Canadian federal election, 2015|2015 federal election]], the Bloc won 10 seats in the House of Commons, even though the party's leader [[Gilles Duceppe]] failed to win a seat. The Bloc has strong informal ties to the [[Parti Québécois]] (PQ, whose members are known as ''{{lang|fr|Péquistes}}''), a provincial party that advocates for the secession of Quebec from Canada and its independence, but the two are not linked organizationally. As with its provincial counterpart, the Bloc Québécois has been supported by a wide range of voters in Quebec, from sections of [[labour movement|organized labour]] to more [[Conservatism in Canada|conservative]] rural voters.{{cite news|title=Boisclair gets emotional talking about homophobia |url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Canada/20070304/que_vote_070304/ |accessdate=30 December 2011 |publisher=[[CTV News]] |date=4 March 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120329062646/http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Canada/20070304/que_vote_070304/ |archivedate=29 March 2012 |df=dmy }}{{cite news|title=Results suggest rift between urban, rural voters|url=http://www.cbc.ca/story/canadavotes2006/national/2006/01/24/urban-rural-060124.html|accessdate=14 May 2013|newspaper=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=24 January 2006|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130806144455/http://www.cbc.ca/story/canadavotes2006/national/2006/01/24/urban-rural-060124.html|archivedate=6 August 2013|df=dmy-all}} Members and supporters are known in French as ''{{lang|fr|Bloquistes}}'' ({{IPA-fr|blɔkist|pron}}). ==Positions and ideologies== An incomplete list of Bloc Québécois political positions. ===Origins=== The Bloc Québécois was formed in 1991 as an informal coalition of Progressive Conservative and Liberal Members of Parliament from Quebec, who left their original parties around the time of the defeat of the [[Meech Lake Accord]]. The party was intended to be temporary and was given the goal of the promotion of sovereignty at the federal level. The party aimed to disband following a successful [[referendum]] on secession from Canada. As with most parties, it has gained and lost prominent supporters over the years. The initial coalition that led to the Bloc was headed by Lucien Bouchard, who had been federal [[Minister of the Environment (Canada)|Minister of the Environment]] in the Progressive Conservative government of Brian Mulroney.{{cite news|title=The Bloc Québécois through the years|url=http://m.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/the-bloc-qubcois-through-the-years/article2008919/?service=mobile|accessdate=13 May 2011|newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=3 May 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110508060618/http://m.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/the-bloc-qubcois-through-the-years/article2008919/?service=mobile|archivedate=8 May 2011|df=dmy-all}} Bouchard abandoned the government in May 1990 in response to the report of a commission headed by [[Jean Charest]] that suggested changes to the Meech Lake Accord. Bouchard felt the recommendations for change undermined the objectives and spirit of the accord. According to ''[[The Secret Mulroney Tapes]]'' he was fired by Prime Minister Mulroney. Bouchard was joined by five of his fellow Tories ([[Nic Leblanc]], [[Louis Plamondon]], [[Benoît Tremblay]], [[Gilbert Chartrand]], and [[François Gérin]]), along with two Liberals ([[Gilles Rocheleau]] and [[Jean Lapierre]]). The first Bloquiste candidate to be elected was [[Gilles Duceppe]], then a union organizer, in a [[by-election]] for the [[Montreal]] [[Electoral district (Canada)|riding]] of [[Laurier—Sainte-Marie]] on 13 August 1990.{{cite web|title=DUCEPPE, Gilles|url=http://www.parl.gc.ca/parlinfo/Files/Parliamentarian.aspx?Item=ed3d4160-8a5a-4efc-a0a6-d65deeb994d9&Language=E&Section=FederalExperience|publisher=[[Parliament of Canada]]|accessdate=13 May 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120228190447/http://www.parl.gc.ca/parlinfo/Files/Parliamentarian.aspx?Item=ed3d4160-8a5a-4efc-a0a6-d65deeb994d9&Language=E&Section=FederalExperience|archivedate=28 February 2012|df=dmy-all}} He ran as an independent, since the Bloc had not been registered as a federal party. [[Jean Lapierre]] renounced separatism and rejoined the Liberals during the leadership of [[Paul Martin]]. ===First election=== [[File:Bloc Quebecois 1990s.svg|thumb|300px|Logo of the Bloc Québécois in the 1990s to 2000s]] In the [[Canadian federal election, 1993|1993 federal election]], the Bloc won 54 seats (out of 75) in Quebec, sweeping nearly all of the francophone ridings. Because the opposition vote in the rest of Canada was split between the [[Reform Party of Canada|Reform Party]], the Progressive Conservative Party, and the [[New Democratic Party (Canada)|New Democratic Party]], the Bloc narrowly won the second largest number of seats in the House of Commons, and therefore became the [[Official Opposition (Canada)|official opposition]]. While Reform finished second in the national popular vote, the Bloc's heavy concentration of support in Quebec was slightly larger than Reform's concentration in the West.{{cite news|title=Bloc Québécois forms the Opposition in 1993 election|url=http://www.cbc.ca/player/Digital+Archives/Politics/Federal+Politics/ID/1632493560/?page=6|accessdate=26 May 2013|newspaper=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation Digital Archives|date=26 October 1993|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150219092100/http://www.cbc.ca/player/Digital+Archives/Politics/Federal+Politics/ID/1632493560/?page=6|archivedate=19 February 2015|df=dmy-all}} Soon after the new Parliament was sworn in, Bouchard announced that Bloquiste MPs would only speak French on the floor of the House of Commons, a policy that remains in force to this day. This was out of necessity; although Bouchard and most of the Bloc's founding members were fluently bilingual in French and English, Bouchard had discovered that most of his large caucus could not speak English well enough to use it in debate. The election of such a relatively large number of Bloquistes was the first of [[The Three Periods]], a plan intended to lay out the way to sovereignty created by PQ leader [[Jacques Parizeau]]. Parizeau became [[Premier of Quebec]] in the [[Quebec general election, 1994|Quebec election of 1994]] (the second of the ''Three Periods''). Because the Bloc was the official opposition, it had considerable privileges over the other parties although all of its MPs had been elected in one province. For instance, [[Question Period]]s during the 35th Parliament were dominated by issues of national unity. However, the governing Liberals regarded Reform as their main opposition on non-Quebec matters. Also, in 1995, when Bouchard garnered an invitation to meet visiting US President [[Bill Clinton]] by virtue of being Opposition Leader, Reform leader [[Preston Manning]] was also given a meeting with Clinton in order to defuse Bouchard's separatist leverage.{{cite web |author=WARREN CARAGATA in Ottawa with CARL MOLLINS in Washington |url=http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=M1ARTM0010399 |title=Clinton Visits Chrétien |publisher=Thecanadianencyclopedia.com |accessdate=9 September 2009 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090428054316/http://www.thecanadianencyclopedia.com/index.cfm?PgNm=TCE&Params=M1ARTM0010399 |archivedate=28 April 2009 |df=dmy-all }} ===1995 Quebec referendum=== In 1995, the PQ government called the second [[1995 Quebec referendum|referendum]] on independence in [[History of Quebec|Quebec history]]. The Bloc entered the campaign for the ''Oui'' (Yes) side (in favour of sovereignty). The ''Oui'' side's campaign had a difficult beginning, so the leadership of the campaign was shifted from PQ leader Jacques Parizeau to Bloc leader Lucien Bouchard. Bouchard was seen as more charismatic and more moderate, and therefore more likely to attract voters.{{cite news|title=The 1995 Quebec referendum: Turning the 'Yes' tide|url=http://www.cbc.ca/archives/categories/politics/federal-politics/separation-anxiety-the-1995-quebec-referendum/turning-the-yes-tide.html|accessdate=14 May 2013|newspaper=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=30 October 1995|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130211091454/http://www.cbc.ca/archives/categories/politics/federal-politics/separation-anxiety-the-1995-quebec-referendum/turning-the-yes-tide.html|archivedate=11 February 2013|df=dmy-all}} A "tripartite agreement" mapping out the plan for accession to independence was written and signed by the leaders of the Parti Québécois, the Bloc Québécois and the [[Action démocratique du Québec]] on 12 June 1995.{{cite news|title=1995 Quebec referendum: A "Yes" alliance|url=http://www.cbc.ca/archives/categories/politics/federal-politics/separation-anxiety-the-1995-quebec-referendum/a-common-front.html|accessdate=14 May 2013|newspaper=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=12 June 1995|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130210231431/http://www.cbc.ca/archives/categories/politics/federal-politics/separation-anxiety-the-1995-quebec-referendum/a-common-front.html|archivedate=10 February 2013|df=dmy-all}} It revived [[René Lévesque]]'s notion that the referendum should be followed by the negotiating of an association agreement between an independent Quebec and the rest of Canada. This provision was inspired by Bouchard. Parizeau had previously wanted a vote simply on independence. The difference became moot when 50.6% of voters taking part in the referendum rejected the sovereignty plan. An overwhelming "Non" vote in Montreal tipped the balance. The day after the referendum, Parizeau announced his pending resignation as PQ leader and [[Premier of Quebec]]. Bouchard left federal politics and succeeded Parizeau in both posts on 26 January 1996. ===New leaders=== Following Bouchard's departure from Ottawa, [[Michel Gauthier]] became [[Bloc Québécois leadership elections|leader of the Bloc]]. In the wake of the referendum defeat, Gauthier proved unable to hold the fractious caucus together and resigned as leader just one year later. Gilles Duceppe, who had served as interim leader between Bouchard and Gauthier, became leader of the Bloc in 1997 and remained leader up until 2011, resigning after the 2011 federal election.{{cite news | url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/duceppe-resigns-as-bloc-leader-after-losing-riding/article2007598/ | location=Toronto | work=The Globe and Mail | title=Duceppe resigns as Bloc leader after losing riding | date=24 August 2012 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110505112408/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/duceppe-resigns-as-bloc-leader-after-losing-riding/article2007598/ | archivedate=5 May 2011 | df=dmy-all }}{{cite news | url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/article/984484--duceppe-resigns-as-bloc-quebecois-drowns-in-an-orange-tsunami?bn=1 | location=Toronto | work=The Star | first=Andrew | last=Chung | title=Duceppe resigns as Bloc Québécois drowns in an orange tsunami | date=3 May 2011 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121024031701/http://www.thestar.com/news/canada/article/984484--duceppe-resigns-as-bloc-quebecois-drowns-in-an-orange-tsunami?bn=1 | archivedate=24 October 2012 | df=dmy-all }} Gilles Duceppe announced on 11 May 2007 that he would run for the leadership of the Parti Québécois to replace [[André Boisclair]], who resigned on 8 May 2007, after the poor performance in the March 2007 [[Quebec general election, 2007|Quebec provincial election]] and internal dissent forced him to step down. Duceppe announced the next day that he was withdrawing from the race, and that he would support [[Pauline Marois]] who had also announced her intention to run.{{cite news|title=Duceppe drops out of PQ race|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/story/2007/05/12/duceppe-pq.html|accessdate=8 May 2013|newspaper=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=12 May 2007|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130315002030/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/story/2007/05/12/duceppe-pq.html|archivedate=15 March 2013|df=dmy-all}} ===Declining fortunes=== In the [[Canadian federal election, 1997|1997 federal election]], the Bloc Québécois dropped to 44 seats, losing official opposition status to the Reform Party. The 1997–2000 term was marked by the Bloc's fight against the passage of the [[Clarity Act]], the attempt by Canadian Prime Minister [[Jean Chrétien]] (himself a Quebecer who represented a strongly nationalist riding) and [[Stéphane Dion]], a Quebec minister in Chrétien's cabinet, to codify the [[Supreme Court of Canada]]'s [[Reference Re Secession of Quebec|1998 decision]] that Quebec could not secede unilaterally.{{cite news|last=Dion|first=Stéphane|title=Stéphane Dion: Quebeckers want more clarity than 50% plus one|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/commentary/stphane-dion-quebeckers-want-more-clarity-than-50-plus-one/article8329073/|accessdate=8 May 2013|newspaper=The Globe and Mail|date=7 February 2013}} In the [[Canadian federal election, 2000|2000 election]], the Bloc dropped further to 38 seats, despite polling a larger percentage of the vote than at the previous election. One factor was the [[2000–06 municipal reorganization in Quebec|forced merger of several major Quebec cities]], such as [[Montreal]], [[Quebec City]] and [[Hull, Quebec|Hull]]/[[Gatineau]]. The merger was very unpopular in those areas, resulting in Liberal wins in several of the merged areas. This was still more than the number of seats the Liberals had won in Quebec. However, the Liberals won several subsequent by-elections during the life of the resulting Parliament, until the Liberals had held the majority of Quebec's seats in the Commons for the first time since the [[Canadian federal election, 1984|1984 federal election]]. From then to the subsequent election, the Bloc continued to denounce the federal government's interventions in what the Bloc saw as exclusively provincial jurisdictions. The Bloc credits its actions for the uncovering of what has since become the [[sponsorship scandal]].{{cite news|title=Federal sponsorship scandal|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news2/background/groupaction/|accessdate=24 April 2014|newspaper=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=26 October 2006|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140515152950/http://www.cbc.ca/news2/background/groupaction/|archivedate=15 May 2014|df=dmy-all}} ===Comeback=== The Bloc continued to slide in most of the 2003 opinion polls following the [[Quebec general election, 2003|2003 Quebec election]] which was won by the federalist [[Quebec Liberal Party]] led by [[Jean Charest]]. However, things changed during the winter of 2003. The federalist Charest government lost popularity. Then, in February 2004, the Auditor General of Canada uncovered the [[Gomery Commission|sponsorship scandal]], suggesting illegality in the spending of federal monies in Quebec in support of Canadian unity. As well, the [[Liberal Party of Canada|Liberal]] government of [[Jean Chrétien]] passed party financing legislation that resulted in the Bloc receiving millions of dollars in subsidies that helped to stabilize its organization.{{cite news|title=Political contributions: money, money, money|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news2/background/cdngovernment/political-contributions.html|accessdate=24 April 2014|newspaper=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=5 June 2006|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140401043433/http://www.cbc.ca/news2/background/cdngovernment/political-contributions.html|archivedate=1 April 2014|df=dmy-all}} For the [[Canadian federal election, 2004|2004 election]] the Bloc adopted the slogan ''Un parti propre au Québec'', a play on words that can be translated either as "A party of Quebec's own" ("a party proper to Quebec") or as "A clean party in Quebec". The Bloc won 54 seats in the House of Commons, tying its previous record from the 1993 campaign. For the [[Canadian federal election, 2006|2006 election]], the Bloc used the slogan ''Heureusement, ici, c'est le Bloc!'' ("Fortunately, the Bloc is here!").{{cite web|url=http://www.bloc.org/archivage/depmontreal_english.pdf |title=BQ_DepEthno – anglais |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060219011054/http://www.bloc.org/archivage/depmontreal_english.pdf |archivedate=19 February 2006 |df= }} The Bloc were expected to easily win more than 60 seats at the start of the campaign, and they did in fact take six seats from the Liberals. However, the unexpected surge of the new [[Conservative Party of Canada]] in parts of Quebec, particularly in and around Quebec City, led to the Bloc losing eight seats to the Tories. Coupled with an additional loss to [[André Arthur]], an independent candidate, the Bloc recorded a net loss of three seats.{{cite news|title=Conservatives make breakthrough in Quebec; Bloc wins 51 seats|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/conservatives-make-breakthrough-in-quebec-bloc-wins-51-seats-1.586146|accessdate=24 April 2014|newspaper=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=24 January 2006|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140416201625/http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/conservatives-make-breakthrough-in-quebec-bloc-wins-51-seats-1.586146|archivedate=16 April 2014|df=dmy-all}} The Conservative Party won a plurality (but not a majority) of seats in the House of Commons, thus forming a [[minority government]]. There was persistent speculation as to the possibility of the Bloc forming alliances with other opposition parties to wrest the government away from the Conservatives. Duceppe, whose leadership was confirmed after the election, maintained that the Bloc would continue to co-operate with other opposition parties or with the government when this advantaged Quebec, but would not participate in a federal government.{{Citation needed|date=March 2011}} On 2 May 2006, a poll revealed that for the first time, the Conservatives were ahead of the Bloc among Quebec voters (34% against 31%){{Citation needed|date=May 2011}}. Duceppe announced the Bloc would support [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Stephen Harper]]'s budget that same day. By October polls showed that the Bloc was up to mid forties whereas the Conservatives fell into the teens behind Liberals in their poll numbers in Quebec{{Citation needed|date=October 2011}}. ===Slight gains=== The Bloc made slight gains following the [[Canadian federal election, 2008|2008 federal elections]] as they won 49 seats, one more than the number they had before the [[39th Canadian Parliament|previous parliament]] was dissolved. In that election, they used the slogan "''{{lang|fr|Présent pour le Québec}}''" ("Present for Quebec"). Although they made small gains in relation to the number of seats at dissolution, they fell by 2 seats to 49 in comparison to the 51 they received in 2006. Also, the proportion of popular votes in the province was down 4 points to 38.1%, the Bloc's lowest score since 1997. In a speech in front of his supporters following the election, BQ leader Gilles Duceppe claimed to have achieved his objectives, adding: "without the Bloc Québécois tonight, Mr. Harper would have formed a majority government".{{cite news|title=Harper 'very pleased' with stronger minority|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/harper-very-pleased-with-stronger-minority-1.707322|accessdate=2 June 2018|newspaper=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=15 October 2008}} At the end of November 2008, the Bloc indicated that it would support a [[40th Canadian Parliament#Possible Motion of No Confidence|possible motion of no confidence]] against the governing Conservatives by the two other opposition parties, and would support the resulting Liberal-NDP coalition government at least until June 2010, without actually being part of the government.{{cite news|title=Liberals, NDP, Bloc sign deal on proposed coalition|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/liberals-ndp-bloc-sign-deal-on-proposed-coalition-1.700119|accessdate=2 June 2018|newspaper=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=1 December 2008}} ===Coalition attempt=== On 26 March 2011, Bloc Québécois leader Duceppe stated that Conservative leader Stephen Harper had in 2004 tried to form a [[coalition government]] with the Bloc and NDP in response to Harper's allegations that the Liberals intended to form a coalition with the Bloc and the NDP.{{cite news|last=Payton|first=Laura|title=Harper wanted 2004 coalition: Duceppe|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/canadavotes2011/story/2011/03/26/cv-kickoff-bloc.html|accessdate=26 March 2011|newspaper=CBC News|date=26 March 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111104222524/http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/canadavotes2011/story/2011/03/26/cv-kickoff-bloc.html|archivedate=4 November 2011|df=dmy-all}} Two months after the 2004 federal election, Stephen Harper privately met with BQ leader Gilles Duceppe and New Democratic Party leader [[Jack Layton]] in a Montreal hotel. On 9 September 2004, the three signed a letter addressed to then-[[Governor General of Canada|Governor General]] [[Adrienne Clarkson]], stating, {{Quote|We respectfully point out that the opposition parties, who together constitute a majority in the House, have been in close consultation. We believe that, should a request for dissolution arise, this should give you cause, as constitutional practice has determined, to consult the opposition leaders and consider all of your options before exercising your constitutional authority.{{cite news|title=Harper, Layton, Duceppe sought 'co-opposition' in 2004 letter to GG |url=http://www.canada.com/news/Harper+Layton+Duceppe+sought+opposition+2004+letter/4511865/story.html#ixzz1Htw6yDVP |publisher=[[Montreal Gazette]] |date=27 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110401200203/http://www.canada.com/news/Harper%2BLayton%2BDuceppe%2Bsought%2Bopposition%2B2004%2Bletter/4511865/story.html |archivedate= 1 April 2011 |df= }}}} On the same day the letter was written, the three party leaders held a joint press conference at which they expressed their intent to co-operate on changing parliamentary rules, and to request that the Governor General consult with them before deciding to call an election.{{cite news|last=Chung|first=Andrew|title=Bloc leader accuses Harper of lying about coalition|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/politics/article/962240--bloc-leader-accuses-harper-of-lying-about-coalition?bn=1|accessdate=27 March 2011|newspaper=[[Toronto Star]]|date=26 March 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121023204043/http://www.thestar.com/news/canada/politics/article/962240--bloc-leader-accuses-harper-of-lying-about-coalition?bn=1|archivedate=23 October 2012|df=dmy-all}} At the news conference, Harper said: "It is the Parliament that's supposed to run the country, not just the largest party and the single leader of that party. That's a criticism I've had and that we've had and that most Canadians have had for a long, long time now so this is an opportunity to start to change that." However, at the time, Harper and the two other opposition leaders denied trying to form a coalition government, despite the letter written to the Governor General. Harper said, "This is not a coalition, but this is a co-operative effort." One month later, on 4 October 2004, journalist [[Mike Duffy]], (later appointed as a Conservative senator by Harper in December 2008), said "It is possible that you could change prime minister without having an election", and that some Conservatives wanted Harper as prime minister. The next day Layton walked out on talks with Harper and Duceppe, accusing them of trying to replace [[Paul Martin]] with Harper as prime minister. Both Bloc and Conservative officials denied Layton's accusations. ===Loss of official party status=== In the [[Canadian federal election, 2011|2011 federal election]], in the wake of a surge of support for the New Democratic Party, the Bloc received less than a quarter of the popular vote in Quebec (and less than 6% of the national vote). It lost 44 of the 47 seats it held at parliament's dissolution, and only added one seat, which had been vacated by a Bloc Québécois member six months prior to the election. The seats lost included that of Duceppe, who resigned as party president and leader. It also lost all but one of its seats in Montreal. With few exceptions, the Bloc's seats were won by the NDP, though the Bloc did not suffer as severe a beating as the one it handed the PCs 18 years earlier. By winning only four seats the Bloc failed to reach the minimum of 12 seats required for [[official party status]] in the House of Commons. MPs without official party status are treated as independents and must sit in the back row of the opposition benches. They are permitted just a few questions each week in question period and cannot sit as voting members on parliamentary committees.{{cite news|title=Duceppe quits after BQ crushed in Quebec|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/canadavotes2011/story/2011/05/02/cv-election-bloc-wrap-652.html#|accessdate=7 May 2013|newspaper=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=2 May 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130520213346/http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/canadavotes2011/story/2011/05/02/cv-election-bloc-wrap-652.html|archivedate=20 May 2013|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|title=Bloc to seek party status, new leader: MP|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/story/2011/05/10/bloc-party-status.html|accessdate=26 May 2013|newspaper=[[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]|date=10 May 2011|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110808161017/http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/story/2011/05/10/bloc-party-status.html|archivedate=8 August 2011|df=dmy-all}} Elected to Parliament in this election were incumbents [[Louis Plamondon]], [[André Bellavance]], [[Maria Mourani]] and rookie MP [[Jean-François Fortin (politician)|Jean-François Fortin]]. While the Bloc managed to win 10 seats, more than twice that of the previous election, it was not enough to gain official party status. The party's share of the popular vote in Quebec fell to 19%, its lowest point up until that time. As in 2011, Duceppe failed to win his own seat, and resigned again as party leader.{{cite news |author=Canada |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/former-pq-interim-leader-stephane-bedard-leaving-politics/article26925216/ |title=Bloc leader Duceppe, former PQ interim leader both resign |publisher=The Globe and Mail |date=2015-10-22 |accessdate=2017-04-25 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170404163311/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/former-pq-interim-leader-stephane-bedard-leaving-politics/article26925216/ |archivedate=4 April 2017 |df=dmy-all }} ===Election of Ouellet and caucus revolt=== The party was led on an interim basis by [[Rhéal Fortin]] until the [[Bloc Québécois leadership election, 2017|Bloc Québécois leadership election in March 2017]] acclaimed [[Martine Ouellet]], a member of the provincial [[National Assembly of Quebec]], as party leader.{{cite web|url=http://montrealgazette.com/news/local-news/bloc-quebecois-leadership-who-is-martine-ouellet|title=Bloc Québécois' new leader: Who is Martine Ouellet?|work=The Montreal Gazette|accessdate=March 14, 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170314202301/http://montrealgazette.com/news/local-news/bloc-quebecois-leadership-who-is-martine-ouellet|archivedate=14 March 2017|df=dmy-all}} Ouellet is not a Member of Parliament and intended to see out her term in the provincial legislature until the next provincial election in October 2018. On February 28, 2018, seven of the Bloc's ten MPs quit the party's caucus to form the [[Groupe parlementaire québécois]] (later called ''[[Québec debout]]'') citing conflicts with Ouellet's leadership style and her insistence that the Bloc should emphasize promoting Quebec independence over "defending Quebec's interests".{{cite news|title=Bloc Québécois fractures as seven of 10 MPs quit over Ouellet's leadership|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/seven-of-10-bloc-quebecois-mps-quit-over-martine-ouellets-leadership/article38144355/#c-image-0|accessdate=March 1, 2018|work=Globe and Mail|date=March 1, 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180228200806/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/seven-of-10-bloc-quebecois-mps-quit-over-martine-ouellets-leadership/article38144355/#c-image-0|archivedate=28 February 2018|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|last1=Allard|first1=Clement|title=Seven of 10 Bloc Quebecois MPs quit over Martine Ouellet’s leadership|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/seven-of-10-bloc-quebecois-mps-quit-over-martine-ouellets-leadership/article38144355/|accessdate=February 28, 2018|work=The Globe and Mail|agency=The Canadian Press|date=February 28, 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180228180649/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/politics/seven-of-10-bloc-quebecois-mps-quit-over-martine-ouellets-leadership/article38144355/|archivedate=28 February 2018|df=dmy-all}} Three MPs remained in the Bloc's caucus: [[Mario Beaulieu (politician)|Mario Beaulieu]] ([[La Pointe-de-l'Île]]), [[Xavier Barsalou-Duval]] ([[Pierre-Boucher—Les Patriotes—Verchères]]), and [[Marilène Gill]] ([[Manicouagan (electoral district)|Manicouagan]]). More than 20 ex-Bloc MPs, including [[Gilles Duceppe]], issued an [[open letter]] supporting the seven current MPs who had resigned from caucus and demanding Ouellet's resignation.{{cite web|url=http://montrealgazette.com/news/local-news/more-than-20-ex-bloc-quebecois-mps-call-on-martine-ouellet-to-quit|title=More than 20 ex-Bloc Québécois MPs call on Martine Ouellet to quit|author=|date=3 March 2018|website=montrealgazette.com|accessdate=28 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180304231538/http://montrealgazette.com/news/local-news/more-than-20-ex-bloc-quebecois-mps-call-on-martine-ouellet-to-quit|archivedate=4 March 2018|df=dmy-all}} Nevertheless, after a lengthy meeting, the party's executive issued a statement supporting Ouellet's leadership but also stating that the seven rebels could keep their Bloc Québécois memberships and would not be expelled from the party for quitting the caucus, inviting them to return to the caucus in the future.{{cite web|url=http://montrealgazette.com/pmn/news-pmn/canada-news-pmn/bloc-quebecois-meets-to-discuss-fate-of-seven-mps-who-quit-over-leaders-style/wcm/771dd787-4bbd-4f05-86db-0d61b4af77bb|title=Bloc Québécois national office rallies behind Martine Ouellet|author=|date=3 March 2018|website=montrealgazette.com|accessdate=28 April 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180304070939/http://montrealgazette.com/pmn/news-pmn/canada-news-pmn/bloc-quebecois-meets-to-discuss-fate-of-seven-mps-who-quit-over-leaders-style/wcm/771dd787-4bbd-4f05-86db-0d61b4af77bb|archivedate=4 March 2018|df=dmy-all}} A [[Léger Marketing]] poll conducted shortly after put the Bloc Quebecois at 12 per cent among Quebec voters, its lowest rating ever. Following an election this would likely translate into zero seats, putting the survival of the party into question for the [[43rd Canadian federal election|2019 federal election]].{{cite news|title=Martine Ouellet won't surrender Bloc leadership, despite outcry by former MPs|url=https://montreal.ctvnews.ca/bloc-leadership-meets-to-discuss-referendum-question-1.3837327|accessdate=March 10, 2018|work=CTV News Montreal|agency=The Canadian Press|date=March 10, 2018|language=en-CA|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180310181148/https://montreal.ctvnews.ca/bloc-leadership-meets-to-discuss-referendum-question-1.3837327|archivedate=10 March 2018|df=dmy-all}} A [[leadership review]] referendum was held on Ouellet's leadership on June 1 and 2, 2018{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/martine-ouellet-bloc-quebecois-leadership-referendum-1.4593688 |title=Referendum on Martine Ouellet's Bloc Québécois leadership set for June 1–2 |publisher=CBC News |date=2018-03-26 |accessdate=2018-06-10}} resulting in the party membership rejecting her leadership by 67%, while a proposal that the party prioritize Quebec independence on a daily basis above all other issues also passed with 65% support. Ouellet subsequently announced her resignation as party leader effective June 11, 2018.https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-martine-ouellet-loses-bloc-quebecois-leadership-confidence-vote/{{cite web|url=https://www.cbc.ca/amp/1.4690336 |title=Embattled Bloc Québécois leader Martine Ouellet resigns |publisher=CBC News |date=2018-06-04 |accessdate=2018-06-10}} Following the announcement of Ouellet's resignation, MPs [[Michel Boudrias]] and [[Simon Marcil]] announced they would rejoin the party.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/bloc-quebecois-mps-return-quebec-debout-1.4694137 |title=Two of seven MPs who quit the Bloc Quebecois returning to the party |publisher=CBC News |date=2018-06-06 |accessdate=2018-06-10}} Party president and MP Beaulieu was named interim leader after Ouellet resigned.{{Cite news|url=http://nationalpost.com/news/politics/federal-leaders-including-trudeau-and-scheer-in-quebec-ahead-of-byelection|title=Federal leaders including Trudeau and Scheer converge on Quebec before byelection|date=2018-06-14|work=National Post|access-date=2018-06-17|language=en-US}} On September 17, 2018, the remaining MPs who had defected from the Bloc rejoined the party and dissolved their breakaway group, ''Québec debout''.https://montrealgazette.com/news/national/renegade-mps-to-return-to-bloc-quebecois-caucus ==Relationship to Parti Québécois== The [[Parti Québécois]] has close ties to the Bloc and shares its principal objective of independence for Quebec. The two parties have backed each other during election campaigns, and prominent members of each party often attend and speak at the other's public events. In addition, the majority of each party's membership holds membership in both parties. However, on an organizational level the parties are separate entities – the Bloc is not the federal wing of the Parti Québécois, nor the PQ the provincial wing of the Bloc. Lucien Bouchard has been the leader of both parties. Michel Gauthier, once Bloc's leader, was a PQ member of the [[National Assembly of Quebec]] from 1981 until 1988. Former party leader Daniel Paillé was also a PQ member of the National Assembly of Quebec from 1994 to 1996, and a BQ member of Parliament from 2009 to 2011. In June 2014, [[Mario Beaulieu (politician)|Mario Beaulieu]], a former PQ riding president and Bloc candidate, was elected leader of the Bloc Québécois. Notwithstanding his previous ties to both parties, Beaulieu has been critical of what he sees as a too timid approach to sovereignty by both the Bloc and PQ. Beaulieu's election as Bloc leader was more warmly received by the PQ's rival party, [[Option nationale]], than by the PQ.{{cite news|last1=Don|first1=Macpherson|title=Mario Beaulieu’s victory shows the Bloc’s irrelevance|url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/Macpherson+Mario+Beaulieu+victory+shows+Bloc+irrelevance/9944189/story.html|work=[[The Gazette (Montreal)|The Gazette]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714181254/http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/Macpherson+Mario+Beaulieu+victory+shows+Bloc+irrelevance/9944189/story.html|archivedate=14 July 2014|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|title=Les députés bloquistes lancent un appel au calme|url=http://quebec.huffingtonpost.ca/2014/06/17/bloc-quebecois-mario-beaulieu-appel-au-calme-des-deputes_n_5502216.html|accessdate=3 July 2014|work=[[Huffington Post]]|date=16 June 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714144354/http://quebec.huffingtonpost.ca/2014/06/17/bloc-quebecois-mario-beaulieu-appel-au-calme-des-deputes_n_5502216.html|archivedate=14 July 2014|df=dmy-all}}{{cite news|last1=Gagnon|first1=Lysiane|title=Will the Bloc Self-Destruct?|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-debate/will-the-bloc-self-destruct/article19215051/#dashboard/follows/|accessdate=3 July 2014|work=[[The Globe and Mail]]|date=18 June 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140622013719/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/globe-debate/will-the-bloc-self-destruct/article19215051/#dashboard/follows/|archivedate=22 June 2014|df=dmy-all}} [[Martine Ouellet]] was a PQ MNA from 2010 until 2017 and ran twice for the PQ leadership. She continued to sit in the Quebec National Assembly, as an Independent MNA, after she was elected Bloc leader. In the [[Canadian federal election, 2015|2015 election]], Parti Québécois leader [[Pierre-Karl Péladeau]] officially endorsed the Bloc, despite earlier calling the party useless.{{cite web|url=http://montreal.ctvnews.ca/peladeau-offers-tepid-support-for-bloc-quebecois-at-weekend-rally-for-leader-1.2388610|title=Peladeau offers tepid support for Bloc Quebecois at weekend rally for leader|work=Montreal|accessdate=14 October 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150810200752/http://montreal.ctvnews.ca/peladeau-offers-tepid-support-for-bloc-quebecois-at-weekend-rally-for-leader-1.2388610|archivedate=10 August 2015|df=dmy-all}} Several incumbent PQ MNAs including [[Bernard Drainville]],{{cite web |author=14 Oct 2015 |url=https://twitter.com/BDrainvillePQ/status/654390732942409728 |title=Bernard Drainville on Twitter: "Av @PJT2072 candidat du #Bloc ds Marc-Aur-Fortin & ERobillard de @kinosdesign, concepteur d'affiches de films, Laval" |publisher=Twitter.com |date=2015-10-14 |accessdate=2017-04-25 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305145950/https://twitter.com/BDrainvillePQ/status/654390732942409728 |archivedate=5 March 2016 |df=dmy-all }} [[Stéphane Bergeron]],{{cite web |author=14 Oct 2015 |url=https://twitter.com/sbergeron/status/654399539793653760 |title=Stéphane Bergeron on Twitter: "Rencontre de presse suivie d'une visite, plus tôt, au CFP des Patriotes, en cie de @PKP_Qc, @daveturcotte & @caaths." |publisher=Twitter.com |date=2015-10-14 |accessdate=2017-04-25 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305135122/https://twitter.com/sbergeron/status/654399539793653760 |archivedate=5 March 2016 |df=dmy-all }} [[Maka Kotto]],{{cite web |author=2 Oct 2015 |url=https://twitter.com/Maka_Kotto/status/650128869471703041 |title=Maka Kotto on Twitter: "Qui est le mieux placé pour représenter nos intérêts à Ottawa?: Le BLOC! @GillesDuceppe Bravo! The '''brigade''' ({{lang-ru|brigada}}) was a labor force division within the Soviet collective farm (''[[kolkhoz]]'').
==The 1930s== The [[Collectivization in the Soviet Union|mass collectivization drive]] of the late 1920s and early 1930s pushed the peasantry from individual household production into an archepeligo of collective farms. The question of internal organization was important in the new kolkhozes. The most basic measure was to divide the workforce into a number of groups, generally known as brigades, for working purposes. `By July 1929 it was already normal practice for the large kolkhoz of 200-400 households to be divided into temporary or permanent work units of 15-30 households.'<ref>[[R W Davies]], ''The Soviet Collective Farm 1929-1930'' (Harvard University Press, Cambridge, Massachusetts, 1980), p.59.</ref>
The authorities gradually came down in favour of the fixed, combined brigade, that is the brigade with its personnel, land, equipment and draught horses fixed to it for the whole period of agricultural operations, and taking responsibility for all relevant tasks during that period.
The brigade was headed by a brigade leader (''brigadir''). He was usually a local man (few were women).
===Land allotment=== The authorities resolved that each brigade was to have a fixed plot in every field of the [[crop rotation]]. A Communist Party resolution of 4 February 1932 said the brigade's land should be fixed for the agricultural year, but some kolkhozes found that it helped forward planning to fix it for the whole period of the crop-rotation, and this practice was formally adopted in the kolkhoz Model Statute of 1935.<ref>V. P. Sherstobitov, ed., ''Istoriya krest'yanstva SSSR: istoriya sovetskogo krest'yanstva'', vol. 2, ...*; `In 1933 the session of the Central Executive Committee of the USSR proposed that plots be assigned to brigades for the entire period of crop rotation.' CXIV International Conference of Agricultural Economists (Minsk, 1970), ''Agriculture in the Soviet Union'' (trans.), ed. L. Kolesnikov, p.164.</ref> In the central Asian cotton-growing kolkhozes, each brigade might hold its land as an integral unit, its members living within this unit.<ref>Naum Jasny, ''The Socialized Agriculture of the USSR'' (Stanford University Press, California, 1949), pp.335-6; Sherstobitov, ed., ''Istoriya krest'yanstva SSSR'', vol.2, pp.304-5.</ref>
===Extent=== Almost two-thirds of kolkhozes (65.1%) had two or more field brigades in 1937. (Presumably it was the smaller kolkhozes, in northern Russia and elsewhere, that were not divided into brigades.) Brigades varied in size from 200 workers in the north, north-west and parts of the non-black-earth centre, to about 100 in the Lower and Middle Volga. The average, in 1937, was 62 people. A brigade in the black-earth had about 10 hectares of land per member; thus a brigade of 50, for example, had 500 hectares.<ref>Jasny, ''Socialized Agriculture'', pp.335-6; V P Sherstobitov, ed., ''Istoriya krest'yanstva SSSR: istoriya sovetskogo krest'yanstva'', vol. 2, pp.304-5.</ref>
==The kolkhoz amalgamations of 1950== After the kolkhoz amalgamations of 1950 the territorial successor of the old village kolkhoz was the "complex brigade" (brigade of brigades), a sub-unit of the new enlarged kolkhoz.
==See also== *[[Zveno (Soviet collective farming)]]

{{Soviet Union sidebar}} '''Collective leadership''' ({{lang-ru|коллективное руководство}}, ''{{transl|ru|kollektivnoye rukovodstvo}}'') or '''Collectivity of leadership''' ({{lang-ru|коллективность руководства}}, ''{{transl|ru|kollektivnost rukovodstva}}''), was considered an ideal form of governance in the [[Soviet Union|Union of Soviet Socialist Republics]] (USSR) and other socialist states espousing [[communism]]. Its main task was to distribute powers and functions among the [[Politburo of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Politburo]], the [[Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Central Committee]], and the [[Council of Ministers (Soviet Union)|Council of Ministers]] to hinder any attempts to create a [[Autocracy|one-man dominance]] over the Soviet political system by a Soviet leader, such as that seen under [[Joseph Stalin]]'s rule. On the national level, the heart of the collective leadership was officially the Central Committee of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Communist Party]]. Collective leadership is characterised by limiting the powers of the [[General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|General Secretary]] and the [[Premier of the Soviet Union|Chairman]] of the Council of Ministers as related to other offices by enhancing the powers of collective bodies, such as the Politburo. [[Vladimir Lenin]] was, according to [[Soviet literature]], the perfect example of a leader ruling in favour of the collective. Stalin's rule was characterised by one-man dominance, which was a deep breach of [[Democratic centralism|inner-party democracy]] and collective leadership; this made his leadership highly controversial in the Soviet Union following his death in 1953. At the [[20th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|20th Party Congress]], Stalin's reign was criticised as the "cult of the individual". [[Nikita Khrushchev]], Stalin's successor, supported the ideal of collective leadership but only ruled in a collective fashion when it suited him. In 1964, Khrushchev was ousted due to his disregard of collective leadership and was replaced in his posts by [[Leonid Brezhnev]] as First Secretary and by [[Alexei Kosygin]] as Premier. Collective leadership was strengthened during the Brezhnev years and the later reigns of [[Yuri Andropov]] and [[Konstantin Chernenko]]. [[Mikhail Gorbachev]]'s reforms helped spawn factionalism within the Soviet leadership, and members of Gorbachev's faction openly disagreed with him on key issues. The factions usually disagreed on how little or how much reform was needed to rejuvenate the Soviet system. ==History== ===Early years=== [[File:Georgy Malenkov 1964.jpg|150px|thumb|left|Georgy Malenkov, the Premier of the Soviet Union, emerged as one of the major contenders for the Soviet leadership in 1953, but lost to Khrushchev in 1955.{{sfn|Christian|1997|pp=258–259}}]] [[State ideology of the Soviet Union|Soviet ideologists]] believed{{when|date=December 2013}} that [[Vladimir Lenin]], the [[List of leaders of the Soviet Union|first Soviet leader]], thought that only collective leadership could protect the Party from serious mistakes. [[Joseph Stalin]], who consolidated his power after the death of Lenin in 1924, promoted these values; however, instead of creating a new collective leadership, he built up an [[Autocracy|autocratic leadership]] centered around himself.{{sfn|Cocks|Daniels|Heer|1976|pp=26–27}} After Stalin's death (5 March 1953), his successors, while vying for control over the [[Soviet leadership]], promoted the values of collective leadership.{{sfn|Christian|1997|p=258}} [[Georgy Malenkov]], [[Lavrentiy Beria]] and [[Vyacheslav Molotov]] {{cite book | author = Marlowe, Lynn Elizabeth | title = GED Social Studies: The Best Study Series for GED | publisher = Research and Education Association | year = 2005| location = | page = 140 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=NUHU3om46M4C&dq | isbn = 0-7386-0127-6 }} formed a collective leadership immediately after Stalin's death, but it collapsed when Malenkov and Molotov deceived Beria.{{cite book | author = [[William Taubman|Taubman, William]] | year = 2003 | title = Khrushchev: The Man and His Era | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=8n7zYmshBNgC&dq | publisher = [[W.W. Norton & Company]] | isbn = 0-393-32484-2 | page = 258 }} After the arrest of Beria (26 June 1953), [[Nikita Khrushchev]] proclaimed collective leadership as the "supreme principle of our Party". He further stated that only decisions approved by the [[Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Central Committee]] (CC) could ensure good leadership for the party and the country.{{sfn|Christian|1997|p=258}} In reality, however, Khrushchev promoted these ideas so that he could win enough support to remove his opponents from power, most notably Premier Malenkov, who resigned in February 1955.{{sfn|Christian|1997|pp=258–259}} Khrushchev criticised Stalin's rule during the [[20th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|20th Congress]] of the [[Communist Party of the Soviet Union]] as a [[Stalin's cult of personality|"cult of the individual"]]. He accused Stalin of reducing the Party's activities and putting an end to [[Democratic centralism|Party democracy]] among others. In the three years following Stalin's death, the Central Committee and the [[Politburo of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union|Presidium]] (Politburo) worked consistently to uphold the collective leadership lost under Stalin.{{sfn|Baylis|1989|pp=96–97}} Khrushchev's rule as First Secretary remained highly controversial throughout his rule in the Party leadership. The first attempt to depose Khrushchev came in 1957, when the [[Anti-Party Group]] accused him of individualistic leadership. The coup failed, but Khrushchev's position weakened drastically. However, Khrushchev continued to portray his regime as a "rule of the collective" even after becoming [[Premier of the Soviet Union|Chairman]] of the [[Council of Ministers (Soviet Union)|Council of Ministers]] (Premier of the Soviet Union), replacing [[Nikolai Bulganin]].{{sfn|Baylis|1989|p=97}} {| class="wikitable collapsible collapsed" |- !colspan="5" align="center" | Official order of precedence (according to 5 March 1953 amendment) |- !
